XCOM: Enemy Unknown is incredibly fun. I love turn based games and this takes strategy to the fullest. In this game it is man vs. alien and we are fighting back to remove the aliens. You control a squad of soldiers that you move and tell them who to attack, defend, or to do overwatch to attack moving enemies. There are four types of soldiers you can get randomly when they level up and each will gain rank and you choose from 1 or 2 abilities when they do. If your soldiers die you have a chance to save them by healing them before they die but if they die they are gone forever. You also have the build up your forces by researching technology and spending resources to buy new technologies, weapons, and buildings.  This is a highly addictive game which can be pretty difficult if you don't cheat (save often and reload over and over again to get the best results). An interesting thing about XCom is it saves its random number generator so that means if you load a game and do the same actions over again you will get the same results but if you do things in a different order you can get different results (the chances to hit will be the same but if one soldier is more likely to hit, he might hit an enemy when another would miss).  The only thing I didn't like about this game is it seems to be very short to finish one playthrough but you could always play again with a higher difficulty or it also comes with Second Wave which lets you chance certain settings in the game. I would highly recommend if you like turn based strategy games.

This is a fantastic strategy game with a couple minor flaws. Firstly, let me say that I love XCOM. I owned the original UFO Defense for PC and PlayStation, Terror from the Deep, and Apocalypse. I played many reboots including Afterlight and some community made versions as well. This game comes the closest to remaking the original and adds a few nice elements in its own right.  Ill list off the bad first. This game is RNG hell! Try this scenario. You’re down to your last move and have a half dead Muton waiting around the corner. You wisely saved your crit happy, shotgun toting, assault run and gun soldier. You confidently streak towards your adversary with only a slight degree of separation as you stop moving. You check your aim, breathe a sigh of relief at the 98% hit chance. You fire away only to find your Muton buddy laughing furiously as you miss. How did I miss at point blank distance with a shotgun!? Next turn my emboldened Muton friend slaughters my cross eyed soldier with one quick shot to the face. This in turn causes a nearby rookie to freak out and panic. He begins shooting my colonel in the back causing her to bleed out. From this point on in your life, 99% will never be a sure thing again.   Now here is the good. Excellent challenge. This game forces you to think ahead and plan accordingly. Do you think you mastered the game? Try classic or impossible difficulty with ironman enabled. And if that’s not enough try out the long war mod. Both tactical and base management layers offer enough strategy and replayability to keep anyone that likes strategy games entertained for at least two playthroughs. Now add all the alien lore discovered by engaging new aliens and base side research and development, and you have one engrossing experience.  Graphics and sound are fantastic. The game presents in an isometric top down orientation for the tactical aspect. In between turns you can sometimes hear the ominous movements of moving aliens or mortified screams from unsuspecting civilians. Environments are very detailed and there are enough unique maps to not see any repeats on a single play-through. Music is great, but still doesn’t beat the PlayStation soundtrack in my humble opinion.   I highly recommend that any person wanting to experience a great turn based strategy game pick up Enemy Unknown and at least the expansion Enemy Within. Despite the RNG issues, the game is a solid, well thought out attempt to make XCOM relevant again. Fraxis did this game some justice for both stalwart XCOM veterans and new players alike. XCOM 2 has already exceeded my expectations as well. I however think this game belongs in anyone’s collection.

I have mixed feeling about XCOM. As a gamer who played games in early 90s allready and played the first XCOMs when those were brand new. After i played Enemy Unknown i had a feeling that this isnt what i expected.  I bought XCOM long time ago and i must say that i found the price of the DLC outrageous later, especially because it actually added what i expected to be in the base game. Since this experience i dont buy brand new games until they have expansions out and they have GOTY or complete packs available. I miss the 90s and early 2000s when internet not existed or was used only by the minority of the population, because game DEVelopers had only one chance to release their product so they released complete products. Nowadays none of the AAA games complete, if i play any of them i have empty feelings, i feel that something is missing, in sequels i have a feeling that 'omg this was in previous version, why not in this' ofc those coming with DLCs but this feeling ruins my entertainment.  In this case i missed that aliens dont invade my base and a few other things, dont missunderstand that, the game was ok, but when my first playthrough ended, i was like: 'ok, that was it? hmmmm am i rushed through or really that was it?'  Do i recommend the base game? yes, if you not played any original XCOM game, but if you dont own the game i suggest the complete pack with DLC (i still find it outrageous that complete pack cheaper than buying the DLC for those who bought the game before, i promised, because of this, that ill never buy DLC but suddenly i got it as gift).  Do i recommend the game with DLC? yes, its awesome, no emptyness feelings, the game got what should have been at release, this what we should have gotten for the price of an AAA game.  The game is pretty hard and challenging, i liked it, need to plan every movement of your units, i felt some classes are useless, i actually preferred only support and snipers for my crew because supports can explore area and avoid getting hit with ligthning reflexes while exploring and snipers can eliminate enemies from long and safe distance.  Base Game: 3/10 for me at least, its my opinion. Game with DLC: 10/10 original XCOM feeling, i wasnt able to stop while i played.  I encountered still a few BUG in the game but usually quiting game and reloading fixed those, so nothing serious.

First up. I have never played a strategy game that I really liked. I got this for free when I pre-ordered Bioshock Infinite, along with Civ 5 on GmG. I tried Civ 5 first, but really couldn't get into it at all. So I am only now giving this game a fair chance. I literally said to my best friend that this was the last strategy game that I was going to play if I didn't like this one.  This game though...This game is great! I can't fault it so far. It sort of feels like a game of chess in a lot of ways. Nice graphics and art style too. Actually, the visuals and music remind me of Deus Ex, which is great. It sounds like the same composer to me.  There are also a lot of familiar voices, which is actually kind of distracting, because I am trying to figure out where I know the voice from and not concentrating on what they are saying...The council guy sounds like the narrator from Screenjunkies 'Honest Trailers' lol (It IS him!) :D  Haha, and I guessed the other one right too! It's the Dharma Initiative guy from LOST! :D  Ha! again! It is the Deus Ex Human Revolution composer too! :D  Anyway, the gameplay and strategy elements are very engaging. You need to plan your moves and take good advantage of cover while getting your squad into position. Then there are squad member promotions, weapons upgrades etc. which offer some interesting choices. The engineering and research aspects are very interesting too. You need to prioritise what to develop, research, build etc. At certain points you have to choose where to go and who to help, which causes panic levels to go up in the regions you don't help. So you have to manage panic levels too.  There is a lot going on here, a lot of re-playability, and very satisfying gameplay. I am finding it quite addictive so far and I am glad that I have finally found a strategy game that I like. This is definitely helped by the way the game is designed and the intuitive, easy to learn UI, which is a big reason why I haven't liked other strategy games that I have played.  So yeah, very cool game so far.

XCOM—Enemy Unknown is the best turn-based game about immigration. How should we treat the immigrants? Should we kill them?  Your immediate response may be: “We should not kill all the immigrants.” Understandable pity. But what if the immigrants are destroying our cities via their plasma weapons?   This game, XCOM: Enemy Unknown, answers that question; in such a case, we must create a multi-national, multi-gender special forces group with which to kill the disgusting invaders.  You see, in the game the aliens enter our atmosphere--UNINVITED--and start stealing our women and shooting our men. And for this reason, the commando organization is made--XCOM. XCOM’s elite soldiers fly to the gas stations and grocery stores and office buildings of our pure Earth, in their jet-version of the V-22 osprey, and shoot the aliens. It is..beautiful. Like Mozart.  I love how the game slows down whilst you see an alien take its final bullet, no longer able to withstand human fire. Do you know the film The Matrix? Of course you do. Imagine, though, that instead of Neo dodging bullets, it is outer space foreigners slowly getting torn to pieces by our Made on Earth bullets; the yellow, green blood spewing from the bodies.   Cross over the ozone layer without a valid passport now, alien! Oh! You can't? Why? Is it because you are dead?  But it doesn’t stop with bullets. XCOM eventually gives your troops laser and plasma weaponry, which replace your metal rounds. And they are worth it, so worth it. The laser and plasma are red, green, and bright. They make the killings like Christmas Eve at night. I actually get the shivers thinking about it. Mmmm, yes. I have..so many memories of the glow, bursting through immigrant bodies. I love to just...close my eyes, and conjure up memories from this game. They are so beautiful.  I almost forgot the explosives. Grenades and rockets fling the xenos’ bodies like rag dolls. Unfortunately, though, the game doesn’t slow down and focus the camera on their flying corpses.  You can also capture the aliens alive. Three times you HAVE to do this. I didn't like those parts.  If you decide to get this game, you should do so right before a vacation begins. I couldn’t stop..hunting after it began. ALSO, you should get the Enemy Within DLC with the base game. Doing so will let you turn your troops into large, mutilated, killer robots. They lose their humanity, yes, but that’s okay; it helps you kill aliens at a faster rate, and with greater force.  If XCOM’s aliens came in peace, then I guess it would be okay not to kill them all. But as the game shows, the aliens do not come in peace.   When the real aliens land on our planet and start taking away our jobs, we should follow XCOM's example.  9/10

Not being a fan of strategy games, I was skeptic when buying what would become my all-time favorite game. Now, first off, this is not Real-Time Strategy, this is Turn-Based Strategy, and the only previous experience I had with such titles was tabletop games, and Pokemon. So I gave it a shot.  The game is set during the begining of a war with extraterrestrial beings. You are made Commander of the Extraterrestrial Combat Unit, XCOM for short and lead a global effort to push back the invasion. With a Council overseeing you, and people being abducted every day, this is no easy task.  How do you stop the alien menace? The gameplay is mainly divided into two parts: all of the gameplay that happens at the base (i.e. sending air support, investigating alien technology, changing your soldiers' names and looks, promoting soldiers, choosing countries to support, and expanding your base) and the gameplay that takes place in the battlefield, with your international squad of customized elite soldiers (i.e. moving them, shooting at aliens, recovering resources, saving civilians caught in the cross-fire). Both parts are incredibly well done and very fun to play.  Now, when I say elite soldiers you might think this is easy, but make no mistake, this game is unforgiving, sometimes to ridiculous extents in higher difficulties. It should prove a challenge to beat the game even on Normal, as countries stop giving you their support and the world crumbles around you. And, as it is no longer common in most AAA games, death really does matter in this game. Do you have a Sniper Major who you spent hours costumizing, giving medals to, promoting and always saves your team? One lucky shot by the enemy and you have him no longer.   If you like intelligent, highly customizable, hard but enjoyable games this one is for you.   And don't even get me started on how good the DLC is.

Xcom is one of my favorites. It's a turn based game for the ages. You control a small squad shooting aliens abroad, and use the tech to upgrade your bases.  The action is thoughtful and fun, and you try to kill everyone, shoot down all the baddies with your customizable laddies, and get the goodies to beef up your guns.  The aliens start out small, they're hardly a threat at all, Then they bring in the big ones, who can each weigh a ton, and your operatatives start to fall.  Your soldiers are all unique, so you get attached to them each. They go and fight together,  but they deaths are forever, so when that happens, it's bleak.  The missions are randomly generated, so they can't be anticipated. They can happen in a hurry,  but don't you go worry, they help your base get upgraded.  The countries are worried, you see The aliens are scary and mean. Balance their degradation, so you can get compensation, because laser rifles aren't free.  So this review is long winded, I apologize as I send it. But this game means a lot, whether you like strategy or not, try it out, or I'll be offended!

XCOM is one of those games that does a few things really, really right, and the rest of the game (problematic though it might be) never has a chance to get in the way. I forgive its cartoony character models, lack of voice accents, and sometimes questionable hit detection and A.I. Everything else is a blast and a half.  Encountering and understanding the alien threat is a gradual progression and continuous improvement over the course of the game. The way the story flowed seemed very logical, even-handed, and motivating. Working with the military, engineering, and scientific wings of XCOM was unique and interesting. Turning your band of merry warriors into legendary powerhouses, nicknames and all, was as anticipatory as unleashing them in the field.  The scathing difficulty, even on Easy, is apparent throughout; if you're gung-ho, your soldiers will die. Period. I liked that, having a challenge requiring tact and discretion.  Or, y'know, you could always just rush forward with an Assault, spot vision of every enemy, and have your Snipers Double-Tap everything, lol.  Shouldn't be passed up. 9.5/10

A Well Done Remake! [KAMGUSTA's REVIEW]   I had high hopes on this remake because I had some great times with the original classic trilogy. After playing it to the end I must say that most of my hopes have been satisfied. They took all that made great the previous chapters and included into this new game: the graphic is very nice, the combat system is turn based, you can expand your HQ by building new facilities, you can upgrade your weapons and technologies, you intercept and board alien spaceships, your team skills advance as they level up and you can stun and vivisect the aliens! What could you ask more?  Well, to be honest there are a couple of things I would liked to be addressed: the enemies spawn 'magically' and adopt not so clever strategies; it is too easy to overpower your team with flying suits, plasma cannons and psy powers; you can only build 1 HQ and team members have their nationality random choosen (the last one is not a great deal, but won't you trust more a male american assault team than a female indian one...?).  The things that really ruined my happiness are the ending coming after an average of 30 hours and not even a single HQ defense mission. Sadly the replay value is also quite low even if there are different levels of difficulty (there are no incentives in finishing the game twice if you fully completed the first run as I did). I guess this also means the Enemy Within DLC is a must buy.   Best played with Keyboard and Mouse Recommended Buy Price < 25$ Score 8/10

In XCOM: Enemy Unknown players are tasked with running a military base who's sole purpose is to defend the Earth from alien attacks. The base view is presented in an ant farm style, which allows you to explore the structure of your base as though it is a living system. Unfortunately in this iteration of XCOM satellite uplinks/nexus are so vital to your success (especially on harder difficulties) that you are forced into a fairly standard base makeup. If you don't focus on getting your satellites up, you will almost certainly lose.  The main focus of the game is the battles, which on the whole are interesting and tense. Cover is vital during tactical battles, and if you do not use appropriate cover on harder difficulties you will quickly lose your valuable soldiers as often times taking one hit means death. Forcing yourself to use Iron Man difficulty or otherwise not reloading your saves is almost certainly the most interesting to play the game and means that losing a soldier is permanent. But it's this chance of permanent loss that brings so much tension and excitement to the battles. There is nothing like the joy of nailing an alien on a 25% chance shot and save a squad member's life, or the sting that comes from missing a 97% shot you thought for sure was in the bag. Soldiers rank up from battles and learn more and more abilities as they do. Successfully completing missions and killing aliens you can recover their technology in order to research it and further improve your soldiers. The visual upgrades your soldiers get from new equipment is probably one of the most appealing aspects of the game. Seeing a loved soldier move up from standard gear to become a future soldier with glowing guns and sleek armor is fantastic.  Unfortunately in the battles the AI opponents do not follow the same rules as the player units until they are 'activated' by coming into field of view of your soldiers. Until they activate they are essentailly one 'unit' and will teleport around the battlefield (outside of your view usually) into positions of varying believability. For instance one time I cleared a building by killing all the sectoids within, and then my soliders heard a sound coming from the neighbouring building. As I stacked my soldiers up on the doors and prepared to breach the building they suddenly heard sounds behind them. I sent them back to the first building only to find more sectoids had teleported onto the ones that I just killed, and were no longer in the building my soldiers heard them in only two turns ago. Another case of this is when my rookie soldiers began to panic and hunker down, I once had a group of sectoids teleport in the middle of my soliders! They quickly took cover on every side of my soldiers and were flanking from so many angles that there was no chance success at all.   Another way in which the game 'cheats' is during some missions (usually 'council' missions like escorting VIPs or defusing bombs) aliens will simply drop in from the sky. They'll either drop in out of view, behind you, in perfect sniping positions, at your flank, at all of your flanks... in other words, pretty much anywhere. There is a pattern to when they drop in, but there is no warning, or rather the warning comes as they are dropping on top of you which kind of renders it useless.  While there are certainly some problems and questionable decisions in this reboot, overall it is a very worthy successor to the original. XCOM: Enemy Unknown kind of screws up the base building by railroading you into satellite focus, and the tactical battles by cheating the rules your soldiers are forced to follow. On the other hand they enhance the experience by allowing your soldiers to learn interesting abilities when they rank up, including some interesting equipment and enemy types, and just making the game much shinier and easier to play.  Overall it is clearly one of the most solid strategy games on Steam despite it's flaws. It is one of my favourites in my collection and I'm sure that will only be reinforced by Enemy Within.

After waiting ages to get this game, I finally got what I wished for in a trade. I was looking forward to having another great strategy game in my library. It took ages, but oh, was it WORTH IT. I'm in love with this game. I really am. Would I want to marry this game if given the opportunity? YES. I just love it.   The game is fast paced, even for a strategy game, and danger lurks every corner. XCOM just says 'Alright, hope you enjoyed the tutorial. Now we'e going to load you with insanely difficult missions where your squadmates might permanently die. Oh, you saved the wrong city? Too late. Game over.' That is XCOM's difficulty summed up. Is this a good thing? Yes. I don't want games that 'Oh, let me show you how to destroy all the aliens' and 'Oh, silly, this whole game is a tutorial!' They waste my time. Recently, I've been thinking about comparing this game to Civilization V, another extremely popular turn-based strategy game. I cannot give my opinion on it yet, but I will.   The graphics are fine, no issues with it. It keeps a cartoony feel and doesn't go too far into realism. It seems a bit bright in this kind of atmosphere, but it gets the job done.   I like the songs, and they match the game pretty well. Not the greatest soundtrack, but still impressive.   Overall, XCOM is an extremely good game, but there is one major downside to this game: BUGS. The game crashes here and there, and it is loaded with bugs. I have issues in combat where the screen is focused only on a corner and nothing else. It gets really annoying pretty quick. One other issue I found is that sometimes when you're at your base, you're stuck there. Seriously. It freezes up. I can't think straight due to how great this game is, with the base building, the great replayabilty, awesome gameplay, and lots more. If this game had no bugs, it would be perfect.   I would definitely recommend this game. Aside from a couple of issues, XCOM is a great reboot to an amazing series. With it's strong replayability and awesome turn based combat, Enemy Unknown shows to be one of the finest games of 2012. I was hooked on the original X-COM: UFO Defense when it first came out way back in the day, and since then I've put in a rediculous amount of time into it. When I heard about XCOM: Enemy Within.. I was excited, but extremely worried it would suck. However, after putting in over 20 hours into Enemy Within, I can safely say it's far from a disappointment. For the most part, it stays true to the UFO Defense formula, with more modern features added and the like. The whole game is less complicated than the original for the most part, which isn't really a bad thing, especially for people who're new to the series and want to give the game a shot without having to spend hours reading and figuring out how everything works. I can't even think of anything bad in this game. The only 'complaint' I'd say I have is I wish the campaign was a bit longer.. however, it's still decently long. Not to mention, as long as you're not doing poorly, you can ignore the final mission and keep playing for a good while. It doesn't force you to finish the game right away. All and all, I could go on about how awesome this game is. If you liked the original X-COM games, then I can almost guarentee you'll love this one. And even if you've never played any of the X-COM games.. this is a fantastic choice to start out with. Heck, I've never even been a big fan of strategy games.. but this series is just so amazingly well done and addictive. Honestly, I think as long as you don't hate strategy games, then most likely you'll enjoy and appreciate just how great this game really is, along with the rest of the series. At the very least, give the free demo a shot!

Think strategically or die. That is the motto you live by in this awesome reboot of the long ignored but never faded title. After your first fight you get to head back to base and begin customizing soldiers the way you want, even so they are named after and resemble your friends and family, giving you just that much more investment in their continued survival. But soon the fights become more intense with choosing between moving your characters to better positions or taking the risk to stand your ground and fight. The enemies you face get progressively harder as you advance through the story (unless you're on a harder difficulty then then they get harder no matter how much you've progressed) and all of them have different ways of fighting you off. The tension is always up to 10 and goes to 11 on those times where you're outnumbered, outgunned and running low on medikits. Even if you make it back to base the tension does not let up. Different countries start to panic and threaten to leave the council that fund your operations. You live or die on the choices you make on a shoe-string budget. You even begin to sell off important assets just to make it a few more days. This game is concentrated intensity and it will have you biting your nails and praying for just one more well-placed shot/credit/day/less panic bar/engineer/scientist/mission/movement tile/round all the way into the wee hours of the morning. Buy this game and don't bother looking back.

I've played the series since they first appeared and I'm an X-Com fan, you may take my recommendation with a grain of salt :)  The first one (UFO Defense) was a blast. It is one of my most treasured games of all time. It involved a LOT of micromanagement, from the 'which kind of ammo' for certain weapons (explosive, incendiary, armor piercing...) to buy (yes, you need to actually buy ammo), to the soldiers selection based on the stats (recruitment involved). You even have to hire scientists, engineers and so on. And then you have the 'proper' game, the action. OMG, it was difficult, but really addictive.  XCOM EU is a different game, not just the same one with better graphics, easier interface and 'dumbed down' micromanagement. No. A different animal. A beautiful and different animal. Is more focused on the action (TBS)... and its really well executed.  I like to play it on a slow pace, enjoying every bit of it. Right now, I'm around 30 hours, and maybe 50% complete... and I'm not tired of it AT ALL... can't stop playing it. You have to understand that 30 hours is a lot to me, because I can only play about an hour per day (if I'm lucky)... and add my backlog to that... 30 hours is really good, I really have to love the game to reach that.  If you liked the original X-Com, trust me, you'll love this one. Maybe you'll miss some aspects, but you'll like all the new perspective. If you don't know the originals, don't worry, you'll love this one even more  Firaxis did it once again. Bravo!

XCOM integrates a lot of interesting features and systems into its gameplay. I was looking forward to playing it for its tactical turn-based combat system, but found myself having more fun with the base management, research and engineering system. However, it does not come without any faults, I encountered numerous bugs, ranging from the non-saving options menu (that I have to re-configure each time I play) to buggy in-game user interface.   The meat of the game, tactical turn-based combat, was an OK experience (Line of sight system isn't perfect, sometimes an alien is right in front of you and your soldier can't see them, I didn't enjoy the Overwatch mechanic, and randomly activating 3 alien camps with one movement is not fun). The best part of this game is the squad system, you get to customize and outfit all your soldiers; there being different classes, abilities trees, weapons and equipment.  Sidenote: I do criticize Firaxis for releasing XCOM: Enemy Within as a standalone game on consoles, but on PC you have to buy the $32 base game XCOM: Enemy Unknown before you can play the $32 Enemy Within, which is just the same campaign as XCOM:EU with some extra missions and updates. I would recommend XCOM: EU, but buy Enemy Within only if you like the base game and if it goes on sale.

The design of this game is laughably bad. The 'spotted enemies get a free turn so often they can just move to flank/surround your squad and murder them freely in their turn' rule is enough for it to be shown in a circus to be poked with sticks and laughed at. The classic difficulty is not classic at all, it's just a losing game against rng roulette where aliens get instakill crits from maximum distance while your guize have 40% hit while standing two meters away, because 'hardocre yo!'.   Due to the above the game can randomly just lose itself for you. Example: one of these mind-numbingly boring VIP search and rescue council missions. I spot the VIP. I have to approach him for him to notice me. I cannot approach him without triggering two thin men spawns (that get a free turn). After I approach him, I cannot move him to a place where he won't be hit with a poisoning attack. After he gets poisoned, he panics. After he panics, he gets one-shot by one of the thin men that literally fall from the sky behind my line in automatic overwatch. Mission failed. 8/10, would rage again.  The tactical battle mechanics have literally nothing to do with classic UFO games bar the 'secret organization fights aliens in turns' premise. Even the most basic stuff like being able to shoot whenever and at whatever you want is not there. Instead, the game carbon copies the core mechanics (one move-one attack instead of ap, no free movement, 4 slot 'inventory', attacking through skills with 'action camera' animations and so on) from the so-called tactical jrpgs. Which is not surprising, considering this is a console game after all.  The strategic layer is more akin to EU, but of course horribly castrated with things like one base, one skyranger, one (scripted) alien base etc., because that's apparently what 20 years of advancements in gaming brings us.

Addictively fun and compelling. You start up the game thinking that you're going to play for a bit to pass the time, you better make sure you had nothing to do that day; or rather that week. In a market full of shooters its definitely a sigh of relief to see that this game did not set up shop in the same crowded district. Xcom is made by a niche audience for a niche audience. It combines a good mix of base management and turn based strategy and is not afraid to punish you for not strategizing accordingly. While not flawless, the game is notorious for its unfair Rng on rare occasions, especially at higher difficulties. Lady luck is a promiscuous little harlot at times and she will either kiss you and whisper sweet nothings in your ear or take a big steaming pile on your chest, rob your money and deem you as a threat to national security by your own government. The dice rolls you get at times will have you pulling out your hair. In batches or by individual follicles depending on your nature, but in a good way. Oddly enough the game's difficulty frustrations add to the fun. Some odd bugs may pop up here and there and camera glitches can break the immersion at times. Still, If you're a fan of the genre, this will tide you over. Add the exceptional expansion pack and dlcs and just be sure to stock up on supplies for that season's hibernation.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown tries to revive the legendary XCOM series to it´s former glory and in some aspects it even succeeds. It's Cons lie mostly in limited economical and tactical options/behavior but it´s huge strengths are it´s charracter building, strategic and tactical decision making, Immersive cutscenes, events, music and story line. More on these below:  Pros: + Music, Voice acting, Immersion. XCom Enemy Unknown really puts you in the shoes of the Commander. Your key personnel continously brief on important matters and give you comments on new tech, items and mission results. This is boosted by excellent music and cutscenes. One of the most rewarding things is seing the beginning of an alien interrogation knowing that you lost some men to get the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. + Story Line This game progresses quite clearly after certain completed missions, research and other key events. + Soldier progression While it isn´t the same as in the old XCOM games. The progression of your soldiers has always been one of the key hooks in these games. To make it even better, all of your soldiers have their own looks & personalities. They throw ballsy comments which makes losing one your best even more (if you are playing in NoLoad mode as these games should be played). + Strategic Decisioning Your choices really count. The losses you take in missions count. Losing a critical mission can hurt you in number of ways, the least of which is getting your best soldiers wiped. The path you take in research, engineering and base develoment count. Your starting continent counts. + Tactical skills and weapons There are lots of AoE weapons like rocket launchers and grenades plus your soldiers skills that can make the difference between life and death. While many of them can only be used once, they are often worth it. + Replay value Each run is different. Your soldiers are different. The events triggered won't be the same / they happen at different times. Mission rewards are different. Your starting continent can be changed (each continent has different bonuses).  Cons: - Very limited number of Economical choices compared to older XCOM games You can't really buy much in this game. Inventory management is dummed down and even the country income is not based on your results but only on how many countries you have under your satellite cover.  -Simplified tactical combat You start with only 4 soldiers. In time you can get this to 6. This is a very low number when you are playing in a noload mode. (In old X-Com this was around 14). Unless you have certain exp boosts on your soldiers, you can only shoot once per turn. With this in mind a lvl 1 soldier can't really anything usefull in the later game. Combat itself overemphasizes taking cover and flanking enemy cover. Enemies (and your soldiers) are practically free kills.  -No inventory management in tactical combat our soldiers cannot pick items from fallen soldiers. Have one of your soldiers bleed to death while there is medkit on the ground next to him and you will feel what I mean. You simply can't pick up anything. For alien items this explain: They explode when the wielder dies, but you can't pick them up after you have stunned one either.  - Tactical combat intiations Most important thing in this game is not to see enemies at the end of your. When you see an enemy, they get to move first. If this is followed by enemy turn, your enemy can move your entire sight radius and get some free kills before you can do anything. After you realize this and start avoiding late turn spotting, the game gets a lot easier and kinda boring. In addition to this you shouldn't trigger more than 1 set of enemies at a time. This is even more important than covering your flank, which makes it quite counter intuitive.   To Sum it Up: To be honest, if you are looking for a same kind of tactical game as XCOM Apocalypse, XCOM Terror From the Deep or UFO Enemy Unknown, you will be disappointed in one way or another. While this game have some painfull cons, overall it really is a good game to say the least. With some tweaks it would be a great game. Easily worth one or two runs. I strongly recommend starting with normal difficulty and noload mode. It is challenging, but manageble even with no earlier experience.

Game was good. Not gonna say the game was great. It was just on the under side of great. Like... if Good was... 80%, and Great was 90%, and Perfect was 100%, this game is a solid 89%.  THE GOOD: The game uses modern ideas regarding user interface to simplify a lot of the unnecessarily complex portions of the original game system *without significantly reducing quality*. That last bit is important. Dumbing down a system for the sake of making it simple is usually a disastrous move, but X-Com still feels pretty complex and strategy-minded despite simplifying the way in which your squads move and interact with the world. The added skill-driven leveling system is a welcome addition, and I found soldier and squad management to be a very enjoyable part of the game. Had a lot of fun.  THE BAD: The simplification process removed a lot of the technical things you could do to improve your chances of survival. It is now much more difficult to remove cover from an enemy because free-targetting on most weapons was removed. Also, the removal of time units seriously limits the amount of off-turn defensive fire you can provide. Finally, the method by which you discover aliens was a nice effort but in my opinion, was very poorly designed. Aliens you discover immediately use free actions to get into cover, and then act on their next turn, but aliens will rarely, if ever, discover your squad if you are in a fortified position. This means that exploration is a very dangerous activity, and it discourages a player from using his squad tactically to flank enemies for fear of discovering squads of additional ones. In the end, the safest way to proceed is to simply have one of your squad run as far as he can at normal speed, then retreat back to a full squad on overwatch if anything is discovered. It feels a bit tedious and cheap-♥♥♥♥♥, and i felt like the tactical element of the game suffered somewhat as a result of the need to cheat the game to cope with the unbalanced discovery system. The maps also felt really small and linear in comparison to the original Xcom, so some of the suspense of exploring an open map is lost.  THE UGLY: The random number generator is a vicious and implaccable foe in this game. There are some truly frustrating moments when it feels like cover has no effect and your soldiers are totally defenseless. As someone who has beaten this game on the harder difficulties and also Ironman mode, the best advice I can give you is: research and produce the highest level of armor you can as soon as you can. It will save the lives of your soldiers. Having the highest level officers possible at any given time is important.  TL;DR: Game's recommended. Some of the facets of the old game are lost in the translation but I feel like Xcom gained more than it lost in the most recent incarnation. Looking forward to DLC/Sequels.

It's funny. Most reboots/reimaginings/rediscoveries leave you with a bitter taste in your mouth.  Ok it's not funny. It's disappointing. And bitter.  The results of years of anticipation & longing, fear of letting down a frothing fanbase that crushes creativity & publishers rushing games out the door I suppose.  But anyways, that doesn't exist here. The bitter taste that is.  This reimagining seems to capture the spirit of whatever it is that made the original set of xcoms great whilst still dressing it in a way to appeal to the unwashed masses.  The low level tactical game which is I propose the meat of xcom is perhaps better than the originals. They've done away with a lot of the tedious micromanagement such as dragging ammo into or out of each of your soldiers. They've streamlined & simplified things & yet somehow still managed to retain enough so that it doesn't feel as if it's been dumbed down. You're left with nail biting decisions such as 'should i rush forward to finish off this alien & risk exposing new aliens'? Or 'should i take that 40% shot or cower in cover?'.  The high level strategic game however leads a bit to be desired. There's only 1 base. & everything just feels a little bit boring once you've worked things out. I liked the way apocalypse headed with all the crazy levels of details in the city layer & this seems like a fair step backwards.  Anywayz, i hereby award this 11 thumbs up.

Percentages mean nothing in this game: 99% to hit can (and will frequently) result in misses, so expect fury at how this game handles probability on too frequent of a basis for it to be just bad luck. Its seeding mechanic also makes suggested 'randomness' not really random since it is all predetermined when the map loads, where procedures occur based off of your actions instead of random response as it should be--it reduces the strategy and urgency in this strategy game with urgency in its story, imho, by forcing the random number generator to be more static. Even when set to 'random' it still is procedural, and by no means actually randomised. I understand the devs' position on wanting to prevent players from reloading saves to make the same choice for better results, but I do not agree with it since the game's probability is so broken to begin with. If they wanted to take a hard stance on development choices without protest, they needed to iron out the flaws tied to the decision.  Still, I sunk time into it, albeit swearing all of the while. Good game, it needs work which will never come, and it needs Steam workshop for mods made specifically to fix bugs and other problems that the devs will continue to ignore (these mods exist online already, but they are not integrated with Steam). This game's problems are too outstanding for me to ignore despite what is good, and the shortcomings are too numerous to like this game more than it allows me to. Buy it when it is on sale, because with no support and no Workshop, I do not feel that it is worth $30 USD, but it is absolutely worth $10 ish.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown, and the expansion, Enemy Within, provide a solid experience for strategy game fans. A turn-based game, its steady pace of new resources, abilities and enemies delivers a rewarding experience.  As the commander of the newly initiated XCOM project, you must lead your Soldiers (in squads of 4-6 in each mission) against an emergent alien threat. Soldiers are fairly unique (certain options can widen the gap between Soldier base stats); each is made up of a mix of RP stats (gender, race and a voice type for personality) and battle stats (Health, Aim, willpower). While unit health and Aim are determined only by class and rank, will power can vary wildly between 2 Soldiers, based on that Soldiers service. In addition to stats, classes determine weapon loadouts, skill trees and movement ranges. Variations in the class (2 choices of skills at 2 separate ranks) can turn two SOldiers of the same class into completely different specialists.  As the Commander, you are also responsible for maintaining order planet-wide via manegement of 'panic levels' for each of your member countries; let panic rise too high and you loose support, loose too much support and your project may be disbanded. Panic levels can be lowered or maintained via performance on missions and selection of missions in a member-states territory or missions provided by your ominous counsel of ominousness.  R&D, base staffing, construction and funding is also your responsability. While staffing occurs naturaly over time, you will sometimes need to choose between extra funds or R&D personel. R&D itself is a standard fair, set your labrats on a task and they'll knock it out in time; which projects are available depends on prior research and your dedication to capturing/killing the aliens. Construction of your base is slightlly randomized (several 'tiles' have special facilities that can be made only there), and grants bonuses for construction similar facilities on like 'tiles'  The challenge of the game is completely customizable, though I would recomend default settings for first time players. Despite the main story remaining the same, adjustments in difficulty (something as small as selecting a different starting country) can give an entirely different experience.  The expansion content enhances the main story line, making it unnecessary* to play the base game, even for first time players. In fact, I would recomend against playing without the expansion if possible, as the added maps help keep the experience fresh. However, the base game still delivers on a fantastic experience.  *As of this writting, there is 1 achievement that cannot be acquired through playing the expansion content

This is not your dad's XCOM. A typically slick Firaxis entry, this is a re-imagining of the original that takes the bulk of the source and transports it into a sleek, cruel, narrative-led shell. The principles of XCOM are all here with some additions, subtractions and lot of careful streamlining. While some stand-out elements are missing (goodbye fully destructible environments), a lot of the things you would expect to miss are shown up as unpleasant memories that make the forefathers difficult to return to (weight-based equipment management, I'm looking at you!). It's a polished, shiny, occasionally eerie version of an old treasure that does everything it can to entice newcomers while somehow keeping the vast majority of the grognards happy as well. Only a few games genuinely earn a $30+ price tag, but I would not hesitate to recommend this at any time, let alone during a sale.

Oh XCOM, how I both love and hate you. I've never even beaten this game, even though I've probably had 6+ attempts to run through it. XCOM: Enemy Unknown, and it's exemplary expansion, Enemy Within is a reboot of an old, venerable turn based strategy franchise. I've never played any of the old XCOMs, and die-hard fans will say this is a casualization of the franchise, but I found this game to be amazing, and definitley very tactically deep. Essentially, you are placed in charge of a top secret military organization that is formed, funded, and supported by every major nation on the planet, activated with... you guessed it, when ALIENS ATTACK! The game does a phenomenal job of making you feel outgunned and outmatched, you truly feel like you're fighting a desperate war where victory seems literally impossible. If you play on the harder difficulties especially with Ironman, you'll bemoan the loss of your troops and the failure of your actions.  Most of the game is spent in a tactical top down view of combat with aliens. Pretty standard fare, similar to the Fire Emblem series with more ranged weapons, but in between missions you spend time at a secret underground base where you build laboratories, factories, and research/ interrogate alien species to help you better fight future battles. A shadowy group of country representatives known as The Council funds you and critiques your mission performance, however, you don't have enough resources to respond to every attack around the world all the time, so you have to pick and choose which countries you want to keep from 'panicking.' If a country 'panics' they'll pull out from funding you, giving you even less resources to choose from. This leads to an interesting moral choice, similar to the old Atari game Missile Comand where you have to protect cities from getting destroyed. Should you try to save every country, or just focus on a few, and forget the rest? The Enemy WIthin expansion allows you to augment the ever living ♥♥♥♥ out of your soldiers, leading to amputations/ enhancements that lend better combat abilities but also make you feel as if you are losing your humanity. In my opinion, since we are all getting lasered to death by aliens anyway, of course I would augment the ♥♥♥♥ out of my soldiers to give us a chance, but it's up to you, really.  XCOM: Enemy Unknown is one of the best strategy games on PC and you should probably own it already, but if you don't, pick it up if you like Fire Emblem/ Independence Day or if you enjoy strategy titles in general. I love that since this game was so difficult, the canonical ending of the game is that we failed. WE ALL FAILED, GUYS, THE ALIENS WON! XCOM 2 appears to show an earth dominated by the aliens due to a complete failure of earth's defenses, and in that game, we'll get our second chance at finally completing the game. Can't wait to lose again!

*Written without Enemy Within*  A good attempt to modernize X-Com for a newer audience, but one that suffers from many of the pitfalls of today's gaming mentality. The game is full of cute additions that quite quickly become incredibly annoying. The constant talking heads (some of which can be disabled in the expansion apparently), the little cutscenes, the soldier voice acting; they simply make the game less enjoyable as you go along. You can disable them, but you'd think they'd make 'fluff' less aggrivating. There are other 'features' that I found offputting, useless, or hindered my enjoyment. The entire 'Ant Farm' base being a good example of something that serves absolutely no function.  Gameplay is simplified from the original X-Com quite a bit, sometimes with artificial limitations that don't make sense when looked at critically. My honest opinion about the game was that the AI cheated, or the game had no idea how to computate odds for various actions. Which is odd, given that the original X-Com; a very difficult game never felt like it cheated. It comes down to the difference in presentation: One soldier in X-Com means nothing. In Enemy Unknown it means everything. That one soldier can be the difference between failure and loss; making the AI 'cheating' or being 'cheap' incredibly frustrating.  Also has to be mentioned that 2K promised mod support prior to release, but then changed their tune once the game came out, including making the game 'call home', which nukes mod support unless you run it offline or without autoupdate. Not a cool move. There's also the bugs, which last I played were quite bad and patch support was very slow.  Despite that, it's still a solid strategy game. In no way do I think it is anywhere near the original game, but it's a solid attempt. For me, there are enough issues and questionable design decisions that I don't know if I'll ever get the enjoyment I could have out of it. If you don't have any illusions for X-Com, or just want a solid modern strategy game, it's worth a look. I'd still recommend the original over the remake.

Just to start off here I LOVE THIS GAME!!! I have put so many hours into this game and had so many playthroughs yet the game never gets old. This game has a lot going for it. Firaxis decided to go with core ideas from UFO Defence and then streamlined them to make them easier and somewhat more forgiving. The story in the game is decent but can get stale during a second game but this is made up during the missions you play in game. As you play the game you grow attached to soldiers that stand out or are general bad asses. You start out seeing them as rookies and then attach to them so much you are literally crying when you see him getting shot right in the face by a sectopod beam before dying. Even if they aren't complete badasses you can still connect even if it is the soldier that manages to miss the 99% shot at point blank. In my opinion that in itself makes the games 'story' different every playthrough. If you’re not lazy like me you could even read the incredibly well written flavour text that is honestly very interesting. On top of the flavour text the game gives off a very creepy atmosphere that overall makes up for the somewhat linear story and keeps you immersed in the game. The cover system in this game is extremely easy to learn and overall the games combat system is easy to get the hang of. The game’s tutorial is extremely helpful and gives you a good summary of what this game is about. The game is also interesting and fun when you are in your Xcom base. You are going to be mostly focusing on research because if you aren't researching new weapons and armor fast enough your soldiers are going to go into battle with huge disadvantages. But engineering is also important if you are playing on harder difficulties. The hardest decisions to make are what countries you want to help. Every month you are given 'abductions.' These are when you have 3 countries that need your help you have to choose 1 and then receive the reward that country gives. For a game nearly devoid of meaningful plot, characterisation and dialogue; it certainly has a way of wrenching your heart strings every time a squad member has a brush with mortality.   Let's assume you've been sleeping under a rock and have just noticed this gem on a steam sale - XCom: Enemy Unknown is a reboot/remake of a 90s classic tactical turn-based, squad-based shooter.   The core gameplay is centred on your select cohort of highly trained multinational supersoldiers, with the general hope to rid earth of a multiracial group of alien baddies. XCom itself is the title of a highly advanced international military cell tasked with the defence of its constituent nations from an unknown threat. You play the part of its commander, and you answer to a Council of the world's constituent nations.   So far so good? Game on.  This defending of nations business comes about by completing global missions for various nations with differing objectives; taking your soldier's differing abilities into account as you shift, turn by turn, into nail-biting trades of gunfire with whichever variant of alien crusader you're pitted against. As you complete missions, you earn the means to research your increasingly diverse foes; with incrementally more valuable and powerful rewards as you reverse-engineer the enemy's technology to suit your own purposes.  Missions are received as a result of successfully intercepting invading craft (provided you've managed your infrastructure of defensive satellites and aircraft over the world's nations), defending nations as abductions and alien terrorism takes place, or on a particular assignment (story-specific mission) from the 'Council' itself. These missions develop nicely in both complexity and variety as the game goes on.  The challenge, and the game itself, lies in the brutally indifferent nature of the random number generator. It decides whether your '95%' aim chance will actually connect, or whether you'll be left watching your precious soldier being blasted into meat paste by plasma fire. Your soldier's innate class abilities offer a rewarding approach to tactical thought as you mitigate the random nature of the gunfights with careful squad placement and movement.  The classes are the centrepiece of your progression throughout the game. As you inevitably settle down on a chosen few soldiers to take on the majority of missions, they gain experience and additional abilities according to their class. These will be pretty familiar to any players of traditional squad-based shooters: long-range, high damage snipers; exceptionally mobile assault units; versatile support units; and high impact heavy units. Each class features an ability tree that provides each soldier with an increasing number of tactical perks to better your chances against ET nasties. Such a careful progression of a chose few individuals make the high-risk gameplay all the more immersive as you will literally cry out with the untimely demise of a hardened veteran. Though the game is ingenious in its ability to never leave you feeling cheated: it is always your mistake.  As mentioned, the other aspect of game progression is presented in technological research. As you encounter more advanced and lethal enemies, you gain more opportunities to better equip your soldiers with advanced weapons, armour and useable items. This is also linked to another mechanic of base-building, where you progressively advance your homebase with laboratories and workshops as you gain the reward of additional staff from nations you've successfully defended.   Whilst so many facets of a game may sound fractured and confusing, the mechanics tie together in a very satisfying manner. Your gametime takes you from an initial desperate scrabble - barely managing from mission-to-mission as soldiers die to superior enemies and countries drop out of the XCom program as you fail to defend them - to a final plateau where you task your honed team of veterans to finish off the alien menace, once and for all.  The game offers a few twists and turns with story missions that allude to a central plot line, though the real enjoyment is testing your favourite soldiers against whatever challenge the game throws at you. There is a genuine satisfaction to be had in having soldiers become ridiculously powerful in terms of combat ability, purely as a result of surviving high odds through your initial struggles.  The Enemy Within DLC presents a new twist to the campaign story with new enemy variants and mission types, as well as sprucing up the soldier classes with the moral quandary that is alien augmentation. You can either opt to hone your soldiers with genetic modification, with more options provided as you discover new aliens from which to splice genes; or do away with their limbs entirely and give them a massively powerful mechanised suit.   The game underlies this newfound power nicely with thoughtful quips from your research staff questioning the intrinsic trade-off of humanity for alien power as you further meddle with your soldiers.  Philosophical tangents aside, the DLC brings enjoyable variety to an already feature-packed game.   Made it thus far? Now the not-so-good. There are some incredible bugs to be found, even at this stage in post-game patching. I’ve been forced to alt-F4 essential story missions as a result of hitches in gameplay with little motivation to continue from where I left off. There are well documented bugs in final-stage missions, especially poor considering the amount of player investment to get to these points.   I’d recommend saving often, if only so you don’t have to trudge dutifully through already-played sections to reach critical points.

I've gotten old. I can no longer play the original X-COM games. They're too clunky, too micro-management intensive, with mechanics favoring people who are colloquially referred to as 'grognards.' Aside from some PC-only holdouts, the turn-based strategy has been considered a dead genre for years. They tried to revive XCOM as a shooter once, with expected results. They were (are?) trying to revive it as a shooter a second time. But as Enemy Unknown teaches us, there's no need for that. Firaxis knows how to make turn-based strategy games where the focus is on actual fun stuff.   XCOM: Enemy Unknown may be multi-platform, but it's not 'dumbed down for console.' The important stuff is all here. Earth is under attack by aliens. You lead a military organization dedicated to intercepting and repelling these attacks. You got a base to expand, soldiers of different classes to train, tech research to develop, weapons and armor to build. At first you're hanging on for dear life, overwhelmed by the enemy's superiority. Your soldiers die easily and often. You can't be everywhere or save everybody. You have many things to do and not enough money to do them all. But figure out a balance, and eventually you'll turn the tide.  THAT is XCOM to me. Not 'Time Units.' Not buying individual clips of bullets to individually assign to individual soldiers. Not 3 pages of steps in the manual you need to follow just to throw a grenade. All that stuff from the old games is gone here. The nuts and bolts of combat and base building have all undergone a total overhaul, and the result is something that is serving as an introduction to turn-based strategy for an entire generation of gamers. Now if you want to throw a grenade, you just select the button. The diehard aficionados can still crank up the difficulty as needed (the jump from 'Normal' to 'Classic' is...significant), or let their aspie flag fly over Xenonauts.  The single-player is the kind of game you can play and replay time and again, since it's never exactly the same twice. (Well, you'll see the combat maps repeat quite a bit.) But there's also competitive multiplayer, and from what I gather it's fairly well-liked. Personally, I never bothered with it. Not when the campaign is the kind of thing that makes you stay up until 4 AM.  So far, the DLC hasn't been worth it. Customizing your soldiers with additional colors and giving the option to wear hats is nice, but not for the money they're charging. I'd rather see other customization options. They go out of their way to show that the soldiers come from nations all over the world, yet the voices you can assign are all virtually identical. Similarly, the fact that the invasions happen throughout multiple countries is not in any way reflected by the combat maps. China, the United States, and South Africa all look the same. In light of that, the fat that one DLC adds a few more council missions and a guy with a unique voice set sounds like a good idea...until you realize those missions will now happen every playthrough now.  Honestly? I doubt I needed to recommend this to anybody. XCOM: Enemy Unknown was a top seller on Steam for weeks, and it's almost sure to be Game of the Year. It's a major hit on all systems, and companies are taking note. Why, we're going to see a new version of Space Hulk soon!

Really? You need reviews for such epic game like this one? Just do yourself a favor by buying it and play the hell out of it, alright?   ... ... ...  OK. Fine. If you really want it, here it is.  XCOM: Enemy Unknow is a turn-based strategy game where you fight the aliens from outer space. The game present to you the story in just the way that you will know the basic of what is going on quite loosely and have you fulfilled the rest of the story yourself through your campaign.  The story is just as I mentioned before. The aliens come out of nowhere, kick the ♥♥♥♥ out of us. We(the nations) form the special operation called XCOM to fight back. And you happend to be its commander.   So your job is to lead the squad of four soldiers(which can be expanded into 6 at maximum in most difficulties) to the battle fields. Fight the aliens through turn-based strategy system which, as you can imagine, you move your sqaud and they move theirs. You have to try exploiting the territory by the cover system, flank system and ♥♥♥♥ tons of depth in gameplay you'll experience in game.   Your squad then will grow or gain ranks. And through ranks comes abilities which will help you in your quest. The abilities comes in two branches which you can choose which one you want your soldier to be.   Your soldiers start off as the rookies and then will be determined/assigned classes randomly. The classes consist of 4 different classes which are 'assault','sniper','heavy' and 'support'. Each class has its own good side and bad side which you can and must exploit it to full use especially in the harer campaign.   The Assault, as the name suggests, do assault. The Assault specializes in close-range combat. They can run&gun, have high rate of critical in close-range and can dodge reaction fire with lightning reflex skill and else. But again, they are still but human not a tank and this game is nothing but XCOM. So don't try have him or her go on ramboing through hordes of aliens because inevitably they will end up being corpses.   The Sniper, again as the name suggests, specializes in long-range combat. They have high accuracy in long-range but poor in close-range due to the distant penalty. You can place them really far behind the front line(as long as the sight is not covered) and still have them shoot the ♥♥♥♥ out of that ♥♥♥♥er who really annoys the ♥♥♥♥ out of you. All that is possible due to the ability you gain when your rank climbs up. This unit will be a crucial unit in your team since they can get you out of tigh situations if being used wisely. And yes, the sniper is very vulnerable so tacke good care of him.   The Heavy specializes in heavy weapon and rocket firing. They do deal a lot of damage but have the lowest accuracy of all. This unit is again very useful if being used wisely. The rocket can be exploited the way you might never imagine so keep your eyes peeled.   The Support is the most crucial class of all. Why? Because they can travel the furthest, have the highest accuracy of all(but sniper), can smoke up your team either to cover their flank or psych them up and hell, they carry medkits and can revive your critically wounded unit. Isn't that awesome! They are awesome in these ways but yet also they can't win the battle for you alone. The bottom line is that you always have the support in your team no matter what.   And moreover than that, you can craft the robot to fight along you. You will eventually have your team use psionic power or become mech soldiers to help you fight the aliens.   The aliens also come in various forms. There are the lowest rank Sectoid to the Highest rank Ethereal. They can kick the ♥♥♥♥ out of you and they will do just like that.   Aside of the combat, You will do the researches on technologies and build facilities. You will receive monthly expense to spend on the researches and facilities. You will expand your base deep down underground and try to balance the panic level around the world and not to have the nations abandoned the project.   The campaing is around 15-20 hours long(for me) but you can definitely make it longer or shorter depending on your skills in combating and base management.  And that seems to wrap up all the basics you need to know to be convinced enough to buy this game.   So please, Do yourself a favor and click that little purchase button and enjoy the hell out of XCOM: Enemy unknown!

Fantastic revamp of the classic X-Com games! It's not an exact replica, obviously the graphics are updated significantly, and some of the gameplay details are changed slightly. Overall, I think they've actually IMPROVED on the gameply of the orginal, while retaining all of the most fun aspects of the original.  The original game featured multiple bases, in this version there's just one enormous (eventually) base to manage, which keeps things simpler. The funding, panic, UFO interception, research and engineering is all basically the same. The combat missions are still turn-based, but they've simplified the interface. You still have a limited number of movement 'points', but rather than make it look like a board game, the numbers are mostly kept off screen in favor of a bar graph, HUD style pop-up that floats above the active soldier, so you can see in a glance what your soldier can do in a given turn.  During combat, the perspective swoops in to a third person, over-the-shoulder view when aiming at enemy targets. This effect is really nice, in fact one of the most pleasing aspects of the entire game is the way the 'camera' swoops and pans smoothly from one screen to the next, kind of the way you can zoom in on a GPS map... it's a nice effect and really engages you while playing.  There's a good reason this game has such high ratings, both published and posted - It's a fantastic game, and for anyone who is too young to remember the series' beginnings, this game is a great introduction.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a modern remake of an old classic game. The game is set in a near-future where UFOs start to invade Earth. It becomes clear that these sectoids are not friendly, and an international squad of soldiers and scientists, XCOM, is activated.  This is a strategy game, and it is a strategy game on two levels. The action takes place in a turn-based tactical setting. The other mode is a management simulation, which puts you in charge of the XCOM headquarters. You are responsible for recruiting soldiers, building support structures, overseeing research, and so on.   The turn-based missions are not based on reaction time, but on strategic positioning and commands. Use of height, cover, and line of sight can win or lose the mission. This puts the battles as more of an intellectual challenges that a brute force one.   As a simulator, the game is fairly streamlined, like a typical Firaxis game these days. The micromanagement is pretty easy to figure out, and the game doesn't let you overlook necessary steps. So it's a strategy game the typical person can pick up and play.  Where it really differs from the original is the difficulty. The classic XCOM is frustratingly hard, and your team will die. I won't say this version is easy, but it has been designed for playability. The ironman mode does make it more challenging.   There are a few technical issues, mostly driver-related in my experience. The game does crash a bit, and some missions cause poor performance on lower-end graphics. Fortunately, this does not affect turn-based play much. The controls are intended for a gamepad, and although they do work on a keyboard and mouse, there are issues with aiming when using a mouse. I recommend a gamepad for this, as it reduces the chance of your target changing when you click.  So it's a great strategy game, not so much depth or micromanagement as other strategy games, as this one is more based on combat positioning, instead of balacing numbers. Which is perfectly fine.

[That's just my personality - if I notice I'm going to lost a bunch of units in a hopeless battle, I don't want to play much more.] But the fault was that I hadn't understood what research needed to be done early and how to balance the economy - learning how to do this can take some time and it's less intuitive than many other games, because income doesn't flow in as much as every month there is a larger payoff.  Tactics is excellent in this game - well just watch some youtube videos and you'll have an idea if that is your cup of tea. All the tactical maps are pre-written, so once you understand the layout, it gets just slightly redundant - but it's not bad.  The technology tree is quite blind - all you know is the duration of what you're about to research, but no details about how that new thing will compare to what you're currently using.  As a personal preference this game is not my favorite, but it's good enough to come back to and get right back in and try out some new ideas.  Will I buy XCOM2? Almost certainly. Ah, X-COM. Few series can boast to be as long-running or as divisive as this one. The original game was known for its complex tactics, complicated mechanics, intensive micromanagment, and occasional silly moments; victory was possible through good tactics and a good equipment loadout. This one... is different.  Firaxis came around over a decade later and decided to reboot the franchise with a risky venture. They simplified or outright removed many mechanics in order to remove a lot of the tedium of the old games. Gone is the clunky micromanagment of checking everyone's ammo and equipment, and of individually moving each of your many soldiers step by step across the wide fields; now everyone gets one primary weapon, one pistol, one armor, one item, and one class that is randomly assigned despite you already having half of your roster filled with Heavies. You also have to move each soldier only on the paths recommended by the computer, which often says that it counts as dashing to walk through that open door to enter good cover three spaces away but you're free to run through three buildings to shimmy up a pipe and take low cover on the opposite side of the map. Aiming is also handled by this same computer that says you can not shoot at the enemy around the corner, but it is free to get a flanking shot on that same character without moving. Remember slowly expanding to have multiple bases so that you could cover every continent and have multiple strike teams out at once? Now you get one base and one Skyranger to try and cover the entire globe while panic builds in the countries you're no longer able to cover! Fun!  Whenever new gimmicks were added on for this reboot, they were often done just to punish old tactics. Did you want to rush in aggressively and take out the enemies before they could do anything? Too bad, mate! Each group of enemies gets a free movement period when first discovered to take great cover against your soldier who just used half of their turn! Did you want to sit back and snipe? Woe to the long-range fighter, as many enemies now possess teleportation, unerring poison spit, invisibility, enough health to take full bursts from your entire squad, and insane movement rates in order to dissuade the sniper. How about using explosives to take out cover or large groups of enemies? Well, actually, just like the old X-COM games that still busts most of the loot you wanted, so that's still the same. There's an enemy type and an accompanying ability to punish anything you might try that would be seen as 'intelligent tactics', and you're only allowed to carry one countering item per person; that's presuming you psychically knew to bring those items along beforehand for that specific enemy hazard and did not mind giving up a different loadout for your team. Really, the only way to win with minimum casualties is to always have known in advance exactly what all will be waiting for you in the next randomized mission and gear up specifically for it. Fair!  The plot? It's actually better than the original, but not by much. Oh, but don't worry too much about it! The sequel totally retcons everything you were meant to accomplish in this game anyways, so any progress you make against the stacked RNG just to get to that next story objective is entirely meaningless. F***!  If you want to get maximum possible enjoyment from this game, then wait for it to go on sale and play it on any difficulty lower than 'Classic' so that the RNG isn't quite as broken; it will not fix any of the inherent system flaws or bugs, but at least your soldiers will not arbitrarily miss an enemy that is only one tile away... assuming they're allowed to target it in the first place.

Only very butthurt purists would dislike this game, Firaxis managed to get a great deal of the core gameplay correct. However, the concessions made for consoles are very very glaring and what is a good game could have been much greater. Some nasty graphics bugs are currently in the game too, also plays too linear and less with chance compared to classic X-Com.

'Save Game usage for Dummies: The Reimagining' is a lighthearted RPG romp. Set in Wisconson, 1956, the game was first released by Blizzard in 2004, then picked up by Ubisoft in 2009, who added tactical and strategy elements, including the ability to customise your Ken and Barbie dolls. SGUFD, as it is known by fans, is rumoured to be one of the most difficult games of all time, with a full 88 keys assigned to various aspects of pitch and yaw for the sea-faring sections. You'll never look at a humpback whale quite the same way again! A literary classic, SGUFD is known to be highly prized amongst collectors of fan fiction, with a level of subtlety, terror and suspension-of-disbelief which is only matched by Independence Day, the movie. Unlike Blizzard's tepid original, Ubisoft's version ditches your favourite Starcraft characters, making up for it with lots of jump-scare shots, which incidentally later inspired the game 'Five Nights at Freddy's'. And Oh! What a stupendous ending - with at least 30 minutes of closure! (wait did I say 'minutes'?) Not like all those other games that tail off with no satisfying ending in a blatant attempt to set up a sequel. One for the christmas stocking.

XCOM follows in the steps of the UFO series and while it's upped graphics did inspire some, the whole system was lacking compared to its inspirations. Nonetheless, the turn based game play and challenging atmosphere on higher difficulties and ironman or the second wave options are a quite nice short term experience for two or three runs. And there lies the problem, this game wasn't designed to be as deep and long like the past games. That is why most see Enemy Within as the true continuation and it really feels empty without it. Yet for all achievement hunters, those two are handled like a split entity and you need to do it all over if you switch to the other. This is mostly a problem for the Cosmopolitan achievement where you need to win on all continents. In the worst case this means playing the game up to nine times. The base game has a distinct lack of maps Enemy Within repairs. And while it doesn't bring back base invasions as such, the aliens at least try it.  If there weren't the problems... the very terrible problems. Most of these are fixed in Enemy Within. And this I might add is the TERRIBLE problem. If you switch back to Enemy Unknown to grab achievements or play casual again, the things they fixed in Within, the crashes, are still there five years later. Patching that? Why care! This attitude is something I would never have expected from Firaxis. The games worst nightmare is overwatch. Overwatch will kill your game at one point, crashing it mid-mission. Especially without ironman, that can be a pain if you forgot to save again. And the battlescanner, despite being clearly overpowered here by working through closed doors sometimes just doesn't work. It does in Enemy Within, but there it triggers doors. Another long lasting companion even in Enemy Within is the UI bug. Sometimes it glitches out and if you are lucky you can get to save and exit and reload. If you are unlucky, you are stuck in a loop. I don't know where it comes from, but it is nasty. It actually kills the multiplayer... aside of lag. The multiplayer could be a quick sidenote, but instead it never took real flight and even friends struggle to play it 'in fun' together. If the UI doesn't crash your mission or the lag spikes relaod a move and count it twice, denying shot or overwatch, the game tilts. It is a chore...  So what can you say about XCOM?  Most of these bugs are outweight by the fun gameplay - for two or three runs - but the game lacks nearly everything. Longtime playability only comes with Enemy Within as it fixes all but the UI bug and with the Long War Mod, it becomes a great game.  If you plan on getting XCOM Enemy Unknown without Within, I would say DON'T! The denial of bug fixes in the base game is an INSULT. With Within it is fine.  So this review is neutral, I would say finish it if you like strategic round based games, roguelikes or a nice short story of aliens. Complete it only if you are a masochist. Either the five runs will crash often on Unknown or you need to do the same base and story run - much longer than Unknown - in Within.
