This game is an absolute delight, but hard as nuts. Mean ambushes, one-shot crits(if your tech is underdeveloped), and just plain nasty enemies make for a tense, nail-biting ride. The management aspects are streamlined, but contain interesting and meaningful choices. Getting your 'engine' going just right reminds me of worker placement board games.   The only downside to this game is a few bugs. None of them are gamebreaking, so long as you have autosave on. Bugs include: - Fiddly free targeting: difficult to find and keep a range, especially when crossing elevations - Elevation: the elevation mechanics downright stink, with different levels flashing as you mouse over them in an eye-gouging fashion - Occasional crashes: Make sure to turn autosave on in the options. Occasionally a menu will freeze and you will have to load the game or restart the game entirely. Not frequent enough to be gamebreaking or even annoying, but it will happen once or twice. They could be the Joss Whedon to the Marvel universe.  That said, the game is well made, well voiced and scripted, and the scenario maintains a good level of challenge throughtout, even on normal difficulty. This is one of the best tactical combat engines out there, and I hope they license it out, or even bring in other IPs such as WarHammer 40K. There has yet to be a 'good' WarHammer 40K game, just mediocre or average ones. This engine and this team could make a great WarHammer 40K game, and I know it's a pipedream, but I hope they get the chance.

============================================================  Summary :  an 'ok' game in its own rights, can be entertaining  ....but doesnt deserve the name X-Com  ============================================================   it should have been called 'Ufo- the Arcade Game' .  the bread and butter of X-Com games are comprehensive micro-managment and tactical, in-depth and entertaining combat. neither is present in this game.   - base building is boring and feels really pointless. doesnt matter where you build what... yes you get a tiny bonus when rooms are next to each other (wohooo..) but they dont matter really all that much. security stations you might remember from previous games, where you would plan ahead in case of intruders..yep..gone too.  - speaking f intruders... yep...thats gone too except one scripted event  - oh, you may only have one base btw..  - also cant hire engineers or scientists directly. game drags artifically that way.  - once your soldiers level up once, the game will randomly decide what role he will play. that can also mean that the guy who doesnt hit for beans is suddenly a sniper and that the one who sniped with an assault rifle a dozen aliens becomes support. sense? no,there is none but thats how it is...  - oh, and your sniper will magically forget how to use his assault rifle he used just 5 minutes ago before his promotion..and will never learn it again. stuck with a sniper rifle forever. this goes for all classes. every class is stuck with one kind of a weapon mostly and can never ever change it bs....  - not that it matters at the end. there are only about 3 guns from each type  - your soldiers are weaklings really. why?  cant carry more than one grenade.support may have two.dafuq..?  - Ai is literally dense..stupid beyond real..on ALL diffciulties. you can blow up a group of aliens in one room with plasma, explosives and mighty fireworks...and the alien group 5m away in the next room will ignore it. until you open the door. poor aliens..must be hearing impaired.  -this is by the way how the game works overall.  clear mob group, advance to next room (or 10 steps forward), pull next group. rinse repeat. alien grps will stand around until they see you...  predicatble,boring,lazy lazy programming.  - once you made it to mid game and have sattelites over every contient you cant loose basically.  - can only invent 'one' new aircraft.  and its not needed. mid game+ even your old jets will annihilate most everything as long as equipt with 2 cheap gadgets and big boom-stick..  - so.much.more  is it a fun game? yes it is in a way, i played through it.  would i play it again? no, no reason to. zero replay value..  is it a worthy X-Com title? no...  its like trying to sell spaghetti in a tin-can as italian gourmet dish because its labeled with a quality name. i regret pre-ordering it.   wont pre-order the just announced next X-Com title either,thats for sure  all in all i would have given it a neutral review, but since valve/steam cant get their sh*t together and there is still no neutral...its negative.  fun little time waster but it has hardly anything to do with X-Com you know from previous titles.  no depth at all just some arcady..whatever thats supposed to be  also..the dlc (at the time this review is written) is almost double the price of the base game without anything being on sale..wutlol?  meh...buy only on sale if you must

Frankly, I don't really see what all the fuss is about; to me, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is an average game which often felt repetitive and unrewarding. The story is uninspired, the characters are entirely insignificant and forgettable, the visual style is generic at best and the gameplay is solid but unremarkable and not particularily challenging. I have seldomly felt less enthusiastic about unlocking new tech for my squad, base, or individual soldiers in other games, and when one of them died or got severely injured before I got good medkits, the only emotion I felt was annoyance (mostly because that usually happened due to unforseeable circumstances, like not-previously-introduced mechanics/enemies, but also because the death-mechanic seemed unnecessarily punishing while adding little-to-no value gameplay-wise).  As I said, the gameplay is solid, and if you haven't played other (TB)S games before, this might be the bees knees, but I'm glad I got this game during a sale- it did not, for me, live up to other peoples' hype, and somehow managed to disappoint my non-existant expectations. I spent 7.5 hours trying to like the game, more than I have given most games, but it just felt super 'meh' in every way due to not going all-in on any aspect. If you want a good turn-based RPG, I would recommend the latest  Shadowrun  or  Divinity  title instead.

Do not be fooled. XCom is not a tactical strategy game. It is a random number generator disguised as a tactical strategy game. This means that there is no geuninuely fair challenge in the game, only dice rolls which determine the potential outcome of an action (much akin to Space Hulk), and the shockingly poor AI which either camps, suicidally rushes you, or completely ignores your soldiers in favor of killing civilians (on those oh so wonderfully designed terror attack missions).  This is par for the course for the UFO/XCom series of games, however this remake of the original is far crappier in every aspect. From the frequent game crashing glitches, to the teleporting enemies bug, to the horribly inept interface, to the constant and annoying computer control of the camera that slowly scrolls the screen to find whatever action is currently occuring, the game is a bevy of poor design choices, right down to the pointless base design.   One of the worst of these is the occulsion of vehicles and buildings (based on grid height) which is supposed to dynamically hide with wireframes, terrain blocking your vision for things like movement. It doesn't work. More often than not, it simply prevents you from clicking on where you want to go, mistaking your mouse hovering for wanting to look inside a building when you'd rather be on the roof, if you haven't mousewheeled out to the propert height.   Additionally, occlusion frequently hides vehicles your units might be standing next to, which have the inexplicable ability to catch fire and explode the very next round regardless of when it was set on fire. Did you just take cover behind a car, agro a group of enemies, and then on their turn they manage to light the car on fire? Congratulations, your soldier is now dead the second your turn begins. Alternatively, you may not even notice the vehicle has been lit on fire, becasue some vehicles are on fire by default and possess models identicle to the ones not on fire.  Range and accuracy seems to be another one of those wonderfully poorly designed mechanics, as closing ranks on an enemy unit doesn't always improve your characters supposed chance to hit. In fact, more often than not, getting closer to an enemy actually decreases your accuracy for some inexplicable reason not covered in the game. It could be moving then firing incurs a penalty, it could be a bug.  You will start the game being technologically and economically disadvantaged, as the alien invaders naturally posess better weapons than the lowly humans they're attempting to conquer, and will be required to research and build equipment and facilities in order to reach an equal footing. This simply boils down to figuring out how to deploy satilites (your primary weapon agains the alien onslaught) to maximum efficiency to ensure that you both gain money and reduce the panic levels in countries around the world. After figuring out out to manage satilites, the game becomes a trivial slog of repetative random missions (shoot down UFO, pacify UFO, halt terror attack) and once at maximum tech level, will see you continually fighting the same enemy units over and over, as they no longer have anything new to throw at you, just bigger numbers of their most powerful units, which are plagued by the same stupid AI.  Research and development is also entirely linear in the benefits of equipment it provides, providing no depth whatsoever with regards to improving on older equipment, or providing any sort of branching alternative (though given how RNG driven the game already is could be construed as a benefit as it quite easy to completely cripple your attempt to playthrough).  The Enemy Within DLC expands on both missions and enemy types (adding a few new ones in, primarily in the form of human enemies mimicing your own units) and adds in two alternate research options, geneic and cybernetic modifications, both of which add next to nothing towards the gameplay (similar to the psychic powers your units can obtain) as all three can only be unlocked 1/2 to 3/4s of the way through the game due to the afformentioned R&D and construction requirements on facilities and tech.  Ultimately the game is at it's core, a rogue-like. No matter how careful your approach is, you will find no end to the manner of stupid and cheap events which occur, including poor map layouts and enemy/objective placements.  A waste of potential that suffers from far worse RNG than any of its predecessors ever did all in an effort to artificially induce difficulty. Skip it.

I don't think I have ever played any game that is so *unforgiving* in terms of having to do everything in a set way. As such even though it can be a lot of fun, it also becomes quite annoying when you realise that you have very little real choices in trms of how to play it. This is doubly annoying when it's not apparent that you are *doing something critically wrong* until 4 hours later when you suddenly realise you are in a dead-end game scenario with no real way out, and you realise that you have to go back to a save you made ages ago to try to make the *right choice* this time; except that the *right choice* is not obvious until prior experience tells you so.  It also becomes clear after a while that the game's design predetermines certain things to happen, no matter what you do to try to prevent it.  I admit that I like games to have choices, allowing for player creativity and multiple ways to make various strategies work; X-com just does not allow for enough freedom of play: some of the ideas were very nice, but just were not implemented well enough to allow for enough possibilities. I was continually wanting to do things that were just not possible becasue of arbitrary restrictions and simplified mechanics.  Another crappy aspect seems to be that sheer luck seems to play such a big part in it too, you can get a string of right missions (that will give you the right rescources, and allow you to build the right things and allows you to control the Countries panic ratings), but you can just as easily get a string of missions that will give you effectively nothing and create a bad domino effect, and just screws things up so bad you end up in a state of impasse. Repeating the same missions over and over can get very tedius and severely destroys the game immersion imo.   The tactical part can be lots of fun, but with the rest of it being the way it is, just so often isn't an enjoyable playing experience overall.  Becasue of the games ridiculous rigidity, inflexibility and overly linear nature I just can not recommend it. This could be a very fun game that could be made so much better if there was a more sandbox+open ended gamelay aspect to it; a choice of missions that secured areas, rescources, tech, science so that you could strategically plan ahead and take control, and play it the way you want, instead of having to just *jump through the hoops* to get to each stage that the game expects of you.  Edit: I have been making myself play it to see if it gets any better, but no, the more I play it, the more I realise how screwed up it is: uncovering more and more critical failures in the game mechanics. I always really try to see a game through to the bitter end, even when its this messed up, but I am getting to the point where I have had enough; and its a shame because I really like certain parts of it. Very disapointed.

I sincerely dislike this game. I wanted to like it as a reboot of the franchise, but it pulls only mild strategy elements from the older games. The problem is that when I think X-Com, I think pure strategy from every aspect. Base placement, radar coverage and range management on a planetary scale, full building demolition, proper incindiary characteristics from a battle perspective, using your engineers to provide saleable components to the world market at a profit. All of these things have just gone away, and been replaced by a simplistic interface, with a story line pushed ahead like it's on rails.  Soldier classifications was a waste of effort on the developer's part. In previous X-Com games, there was no specialization. People don't operate that way. They are all soldiers, mostly equally capable of doing the same things. Some have faster reaction or aim scores, but all of them can weild a rocket launcher or shotgun.   The true successor to the Xcom series is Xenonauts, and even that missed the mark.  If someone were to look for an uncomplicated game in the genre, I would point them towards the new Shadowrun series. It has most of the same elements, but doesn't adulterate any old franchises by removing much of the complexity of the system originally created.  I realize that I will never see a better version of X-Com: Apocalypse, and that really disappoints me.

Long and the short of it (TL;DR): Good game. Solid game play. Enjoyable. Can be difficult at times (lol). Not an FPS. Optional soldier voices, kill cam, etc. If you're a die hard x-com fan that believes this is blasphemy: don't play this game. Cause you'll never enjoy it. Let the rest of us enjoy this little gem.  While I didn't play too many of the original X-Com games, I did play the first one. This is no direct replacement for the old one, and definitely doesn't have the deep micromanagement that X-Com:UFO Defense had. What it does have are smaller squads (Think more like a kill team/seal team six) with abilities to round them out. It gives more meaning to individual soldiers and utilizing their abilities against a larger alien force. Imagine storming an alien battleship with six elite soldiers (if you're doing it right) armed with the proper gear and class abilities to work together as a cohesive group.   Another thing which I was worried about was map size. Welp, definitely not worried after doing my first playthrough (Classic difficulty, Ironman). The larger maps are rediclously huge, which makes me happy there were not as many soldiers being ordered about as it would take a long time to get done.  If you're looking for a remake, look to Xenonaughts (closer to a reskin and remake in an earlier time period, and which will be finished...sometime). If you're looking for one of the better X-COM games that is more a reimagining (and from what I understand comes closer to what Gallop wanted in the game) then give this a shot. The Demo doesn't do it justice, look for a sale or find a friend who'll let you give it a whirl. It is still a difficult game (Hell, I had to start over/quit and start a new game 10x because I made a tactical error or made a poor tactical decision, etc.) So don't go in thinking it'll be a cake walk.   Most importantly, if you do grab it. Have fun. :)

One of my favourite games of all time.. and I play a LOT of games.   The accessible but deep tactical combat are easy to get into and create lots of fun scenarios. The game also throws tons of fun gadgets, powers, perks at you as the game progresses, making you feel like you are being justly rewarded for your perserverance against the alien invasion.   I think part of what makes xcom's progression so fun is the fact that the upgrades you earn actually let you employ new strategies and change the way you play.. instead of just giving lame % modifiers all the time. For example, if you keep your soldiers alive over the course of your campaign, some of them will develop nearly superhuman skills. When augmented with some of the more advanced gear that you develop later, these troops will litterally dictate the way you play every mission, and their deaths will feel absolutely terrible, and make you want to tirumph even more.  That being said, the core game actually total trash...when compared to how good it is when combined with the ENEMY WITHIN expansion and LONGWAR mod. These two additions make the game INCREDIBLE. Every few months I feel compelled to come back and try out a new ironman playthrough... and get sucked in for 40+ hours.   To be honest XCOM enemy unknow, and especially 'Enemy within' are both pretty poorly paced and balanced, but the free longwar mod off xcom nexus fixes all of that. The game becomes essentially a desperate, tense, and extremely rewarding war simulation. The vanilla game is fun in its own right, but gives you too many powerful tools like mechanized suits too early in the game in a way that doest make too much sense.. and dont give the aliens enough of a numbers or technological advantage at endgame.   Anyways. Get this game. If you like sci-fi, if you like tactical games, if you like rouge-like punishment, if you like good games.. get xcom... and for god sake get enemy within and longwar, otherwise youd be wasting your money on this.

I was very excited when I heard Xcom was being redone, and that it would stay true to the original. Bought it on the first day and didn't regret it, lived up to all the expectations. At first little things like the cover system made me uneasy as it was different mechanics than the original, but after playing it a few hours realized it was a good change. Xcom is my favorite game of all time, and I have enjoyed this remake very much I would highly recommend it both to players of the original and new players to the franchise.   That said everything has its cons, and this is what I didn't like very much about Enemy Unknown: - The base in it's new panel shape is not very good, I liked more the top down perspective form the original. I don't thinks it adds anything to the table, it actually takes away from the original. In the original Xcom you design your base and when aliens attacked it you actually fought in your own designed base with its pros and flaws.This was very fun and added a layer of entertainment when designing your base. In the new one you supposedly watch your crew do everything things, but really you never see anything and the visuals seem clumsy while navigating it. If there is something I could change from UO it's this. - I played the expansion game and after some 20 or 30 hours of gameplay the file corrupted and I lost all my progress. This is inexcusable, I just stopped playing after that as I have no guarantee that I will lose everything suddenly. - They took away some of the mystery and eerie atmosphere that made the original great. For example I don't think greys should move like monkeys, it makes me feel that they are not threatening at all (even though I think they took this decision for the very reason of making it feel more threatening, it had the opposite effect). This goes the same for the tall thin guys, they feel animalistic and personally I think a mysterious intelligent alien is much more scary and threatening than a guy that moves like a monkey. In the same vein the music isn't quite right.  Still with all these issues the game is great. Definetely worth buying it even full price.

Being a fan of the original XCOM franchise, I was excited to hear about Enemy Unknown. As I learned more about the title, I was more then elated to know the developers took the time to experience the original in order to be as faithful as they possibly could be and it definitely shows.   For the most part, Enemy Unknown stays very close to the original franchise. From the creation of the base to researching new alien life forms it's apparent that they didn't want to stray to far from the original formula but they have taken a few liberties.   Most of these changes happen at the combat level where fitting your crew members with extra accessories has been taken down significantly. With only two spaces regulated toward carrying things such as grenades and weapon enhancements, fitting your crew gets a bit tricky when deciding who gets to carry what.   Gone are the time units that determined movement, attack style, etc. Though there is still a cost in everything you do this process is a bit more streamlined and a lot more forgiving then in the past. Another interesting addition is the squad upgrades as members of your team receive not only extra attributes but soldier classes as well.   These upgrades involve special abilities like fire suppression, headshot, extra movement, and more. As your soldier continues to increase rank, more abilities become available. Another significant difference in this game is the amount of soldiers you can take on a mission. You are regulated to carrying just four soldiers to begin with and 6 total.    While originally I was happy with Enemy Unknown, I felt the DLC Enemy Within was the game that we really deserved. Enemy Unknown tried some new things but Enemy Within honestly set the franchise apart from it predecessor. Enemy within gave us new ground adding to it the ability to augment soldier abilities through gene or robotic development.   It also gave us a different type of threat one that will give players an even bigger challenge then what Enemy Unknown had to offer. I intently suggest anyone interested in checking out this title skip Enemy Unknown entirely and just play Enemy Within as they are both the same game when it comes to progression and story telling.   If you're just experiencing XCOM for the first time, then this is definitely a game I encourage you to play. If you've played the previous XCOM titles you'll be right at home with this next gen offering. While there is still a great deal of elements that are gone from the original, I honestly have no real complaints when it comes to this new offering and I'm just happy to see it come back and get the upgraded treatment that it deserves.

Proof positive that not everything needs to be a first-person shooter (not that there's anything wrong with that).  Okay, fine, details. You don't have to be familiar with the series to appreciate the concept - nutshelled as 'ALIENS WRECKING OUR STUFF KILL THEM TAKE THEIR STUFF STUDY IT TO KILL THEM BETTER' - and there's little pesky plot to get in the way of managing the crisis. In fact, 'crisis management' is probably a better name for this type of game, as it blends sim elements with turn-based strategy to deal with alien threats across the globe.  As hybrid games go, XCOM hits the sweet spot that makes it very easy to keep playing, regularly introducing new mechanics, toys, and threats to deal with. You'll feel the difference as you unlock new tech, and feel is the right word for it; it's immensely satisfying to start flinging lasers and UFOs right back at the enemy. Environments are destructible on a Silent Storm scale, meaning you can blast through a wall if doors and windows are inconvenient or too boring. Rockets and grenades become tools for the imaginative.  It's not always fair, even by hardcore standards, and I would caution against an Ironman run on your first time. There are too many bugs and interface glitches that can ruin your day in a single turn, sometimes by spawning actual bugs which kill your team then reanimate the corpses to kill the rest of your team. It's that kind of game.  Here's the bottom line. Do you like turn-based strategy? Do you enjoy advancing under overlapping cover, trying to coax foul Xenos into your carefully-arranged chokepoint? Do you dream of managing base construction so your power generators are linked for redundant bonuses? Can you live with occasionally fussy movement controls on multi-level missions? Then go welcome them to Earth already.

I've owned and played this game for a while. Only now have I come around to writing a review for it.  In a nutshell, I would say:  - If you are a hardcore tactical gamer, I would give this game a 6.5/10. You'll have definitely played more in-depth tactics games. While this game has good graphics and a relatively streamlined interface and gameplay, you may find it lacking. You may find more tactical satisfaction in a game like Xenonauts. Don't get me wrong, this game still has the potential to be very fun for you.  - If you are a person who enjoys turn-based tactics games, and not too hardcore, I would give this game an 8/10. You are probably going to enjoy this game. I didn't give it a perfect score for this group because if you play long enough, you will eventually wish that they had done more to make the game feel a little more complete. Until then, you'll probably enjoy dozens and dozens of hours of it, especially if you purchase the expansion, ENEMY WITHIN.  - If you are a casual gamer who does not enjoy tactics games, I would give this a 6/10. This game was based on the classic game of X-Com and has come back with new things that are good, and bad that many new and old fans have debated on about for close to 2 years. For this review I will not be telling you wether or not to buy this game, insted I would like you to take this information as what this game is about, and as good start or end to making your choice to buy this game, or not. I'm also puting this review in the postitive posts about the game because I would like more poeple to see that even thought steam has implamented this system for reviews, I feel that this positive and negitive reviews has only seperated the good from the bad reviews. I know that steam has the power to change this but, it would only be for the worse. However with out further extending this little review of steam's review system, I give you Xcom: Enemy Unknown.    The plot of Xcom Enemy Unknown is somewhat of a simple one. The game starts with the Alien attack on Earth and then Earth's UN create the Xcom project which is an elite taskforce that was created to combat the alien threat. You (the player) are a pointed as leader of the Xcom project and your job is to make sure that you can protect the human race from being wiped out by using the skills as a leader in battle and in construction and progress of the Xcom project. With that Xcom begins and then you move the plot along by doing sertain plot missions that advance the plot, like collecting Alien bodies, capturing Aliens alive, defeating Alien leaders, defeating Aliens that have attacked a major city, saving civilians, nations, and leaders of nations and lastly using your two most important teams to create/discover new weapons, armor, and important and relavent info on Alien combatants and new and better upgrades for your soilders. Sadly the plot itself has little to explain about the Aliens and more to say about the three charaters of its plot (that being its field commander who you will be for most of the game when in combat sections, the lead scientist who commands the expert team of scientists, and the lead engineer who is the only character that ever brings up serious questions, gives the game slight humor, and adds more character to the story more then the other two combined), and how the Aliens are more or less plain bullies to the human race for no reason. In any case the story hops from new discovery to defeating the main Alien base, and then new discovery, and new Alien threat, and so on untill you reach a point when you discover the main mother ship which contains the leader of all the Aliens. The story actully comes to a swift and quick close to the end when the story reveals the leader of the Alien forces, and gives that character little to no understanding of what they were or what their motive was. The story only ends with one of the most important soilders (that was required to get to that level by the way) sacrifice themself to save the world. In short the story is a short one, but unlike Portal which used many important points to get across what was going on, and alow things to be added on like Doug Rattmann's lairs and out of testing facility areas to create a better understanding of what kind of situation you were realy in. However this story doesn't do that insted it focuses on what the Aliens are doing and doesn't give enough chararcter and emotion into its own story to realy make you care about it.   The gameplay as guessed is a mimic of original X-Com's gamplay of turn based strategy combat with some new twists that are for the most part on the good side. First off the soilders that you are given are equipped with the basic tools of war (an assault rifle, a pistol, and a grenade) and for the start of the game this is ok. The amount of soilders you carry in to combat (without upgrades) is about 4 and you can upgrade this number to 6 by leveling your self up (more on that later). Now with the vastley decreased numbers you have compared to the previous X-Com, changes have been made to make sure that combat will not be unfair for you and your troops. For example a cover system has been created to protect your troops from on coming fire and has now prevented your troops from standing out in the open. These upgrades also alow your troops to move very fast around the battlefield, take more hits, deal more damage, give defensive protection, give them stealth, alow them to control the minds of enemy Aliens, and more. Now with all these upgrades does come a downside, and as you play this game you will realise that even with the great improvements that have been brought to the table it has been matched with its down sides, along with problems that can be made about its original to this that should have been rethought. First to start the upgrades that are given to you troops are thee most hardest things to come by because they need to be researched, then you need to gather the materials, and then pay for them on top of that. Now even though that doesn't sound hard keep in mind that these materials can only be gathered by Alien encounters and even though this would be acceptable if the game accommodated in a more fequent encounters, but it doesn't untill the half way point when the game floods you with a spike that doesn't leave untill you beat the game. With this it creates an unbalanced troops that are ether under armored, or under leveled by the Aliens that you are combating at that point of time. Now at this point this is where the game could be called unfair to any and all that play it, but that is were the battle saves come in and only soften the blow that this spike will have on your progress. You see these battle saves are just normal saves that you can do in battle. These saves can be extremely help full by alowing you to rewind to a point that you made a mistake and you could fix it, but during the begining of the game you will not use them because the game is fair enough for you to not want to use the battle saves, and the game does not tell you about them to begin with. This save is invaluable for the spike of the game, but can and/or will be unreliable, and thus this brings us to the biggest problems that this game sufers from.  To begin, the game (since its release) has come under the rightfull fire of bugs and glitchs that were mostly left in the game and thankfuly some were patched and we now have a some what cleaner game, but as any one who owns this game can tell you their are still bugs that can completely force you to restart everything, and make you lose progress (look at 'Reasons why we hate Xcom Enemy Unknown' for good refrence). Also a bugy game is not all you have to deal with; this game second fault is a gameplay feature that is the bane of the game's over all worth, the percentage system. The percentage system is a simple numbers system that caluclates the chances of your soilder hiting the Alien opponent. Percentages range from the regular 0% to 100% with 0% being no chance of hiting the target and 100% being that you are guaranteed to hit. This system is an aggravating experience to say the least becuase of how much the numbers that the game provides you are unreliable to begin with. Everyone who has played this game or has known about this game knows the infamous '99% miss' shot that will agravate the player to no end, but that joke is far more real then it seems. There has been more then a fair share of moments when the game has told me there was 79% to hit and it missed.    Unfortunately due to the lack of proper planing and time management that has been in this review of which I planed to only take an hour or 2, has now forced me to quit at up to 7 hours of typing. I would like to thank all who took time to read this and to thank a sertain search engine that helped me correct many of the simple mistakes that I have made. I know that I have alot more mistakes in here then I realise, but I hope you have found this review usefull. Sorry :(

Incredible game fluidity. Intuitive user interface. Impressionable graphics. XCOM: Enemy Unknown pulls all the right stops in all the right places, successfully streamlining and vastly improving upon the old-school retro XCOM which was one of the hallmarks of the turn-based genre.  XCOM: EU has simple core gameplay divided between base management and combat missions. Base management is very fluid and simple to understand but requires careful manipulation of resources to reach the overarching goal. Combat is incredible responsive, and punishing in the nature which one wrong miscalculation could end up extremely costly. Both are done to exquisite impeccability in graphics, interface, and core design.  The elephant in the room is, of course, how well it stacks up against its predecessor. Yes, it's simplified in a sense. Yes, some of the micromanagement has been taken out to elucidate the game for more casual audiences. But, in a general sense, the game retains most of its strategic depth. Tactical deployment still requires careful maneuvering and calculation of dispositions. Base and resource management still play a large role in grand strategy.   P.S. Definitely check out the iOS equivalent.  A masterpiece in turn-based strategy. 88/100

Let me just start this review of by saying: This game is fantastic... It is, however, not 1993 XCOM with updated graphics. If that's what you wanted, don't buy this game and please don't bother us by giving 0 point reviews here.  As I said, this game is different from UFO: EU(X-com: UFO Defence in america) it is however not worse or dumbed down. They may have simplified the tactical combat, but simplifying is not the same as dumbing down. Dumbing down is making the game easier and losing strategic depth in the process, simpifying is making a game easier to understand while trying to maintain or improve strategical depth.   And XCOM: EU does the latter. The strategic base management is probably even more complicated than it was in the original and the tactical combat is, while streamlined and symplified, just as deep or even deeper than the original game.  It now involves units working together instead of having 14 nearly identical soldiers just scouting if every direction. Ammo is now more important unlike what many 1993 fanboys are saying. Guns still need reloading you just don't need to equip your soldiers with ammo anymore. And most of all there's the completely new cover system. Now, when you move your soldiers, you actually need to think about flanking aliens, because shooting aliens in full cover isn't going to kill them. I've come across a situation where my assault soldier tried to flank an alien but revealed another alien in the process which left him exposed. I then moved my support soldier in to throw a smoke grenade to protect my assault and used my heavy to suppress the flanking alien to avoid him shooting at my assault... Tactical situations like that would almost never occur in the original X-com so i completely disagree wit people who say this game is dumbed down.   The things that were simplified are mainly things like Time Units and i think the new system is actually better. It might kill the nostalgia a bit but this system is faster, easier and makes every decision more important and rewarding.

I just can't stop playing this game.  The base, unmodded version of this game gave me a good 100+ hours of play. I'm not one of those types to get to the end and beat it as quickly as possible - I drag things on, get a good group of experienced soldiers, etc. In one game, I actually had a group of soldiers with kill counts in the 900s. That should give you an idea of how long I like to play a game!  Ultimately though, even on Impossible Iron Man Mode (hardest difficulty, only one save), I could get through the game with hardly any losses at all. When the expansion dropped, I beat the entire thing in IIMM in one sitting. After you play the game for 50 or so hours, you start to understand the patterns of how the aliens function in battle. It becomes all too easy to lure them 1-2 at a time into a kill squad, without your guys taking a single hit. There are also various glitches (I'll let you figure them out) that make the battles completely one-sided - certain angles that really give you the advantage, for example.  Then, I discovered 'The Long War'. It's a mod on Nexus that breathes new life into this game, and boy does it. I tried doing an IIMM run in Long War, and got my rump handed to me! I've since logged another 100+ hours in TLW, and am still playing new games in it. I highly recommend installing this mod!  Being a veteran of the original X-Com games isn't a requirement. The gameplay is completely different, and nothing in this game assumes that you've played the pervious. As a veteran of the first, I can still highly recommend this game. I'll be playing it all the way up until the day the second one launches!

What is this game?  Essentially, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a turn-based battlefield tactics/base management game, where you command a small group of elite military operatives against an invading alien force, killing the attackers, rescuing civilians, and blowing things to Hell and back.   What's good?   Pretty much everything. With the exceptions of a few flaws I'll get to later, almost everything about this game is brilliant. The two main gameplay elements, turn-based military strategy and base managment, both work well, each standing up on their own two feet, but combining together in a brilliant way. What you do in your base affects your troops in the field, and vice-versa, so the game really rewards you for clever tactics and strategy in both areas. The graphics, while less than perfect, are as good as they need to be, and since the joy of this game comes less from spectacle and more from the reward of good strategy, the lower-end graphics don't let the game down.   The combat system works beautifully, and while there's random number generation to keep it tense, you have enough control over the shooting that you never feel like it's completely up in the air (unless you're playing badly). The four classes are unique enough in their own ways to each be highly useful in battle, and this game has one of the greatest modding communities I've seen in years. This game is phenomenal, and if you enjoy more thinky, strategic games, you should absolutely pick up not just the base game, but the DLC as well.   What's bad?  As much as I like this game, there's a few things that bug me a little bit. Some of these are extremely subjective, though, so take them with huge amounts of salt, as they may not bother you in the same way they bother me.   Most of the choices in this game are either absolutely pointless, or ridiculously contrived. Let me give you an example. At random times in the game, aliens will invade and attack three different cities. Panic will rise in the countries they attack, and I can only defend one of the cities. WHY? I have 20 troops twiddling their thumbs back at the base while 4 of my soldiers go to defend one of the cities, so why can't I go and take care of the others?   From the other end of the spectrum, you spend a portion of the game upgrading weapons and armor for your troops. But the issue I have with this is that any new weapons you get will always be better than your old weapons in every single way. You go from ballistic to beam to plasma, but plasma guns will always shoot more accurately and do more damage than beam weapons, no matter what. Personally, I would have liked a bit more of a difficult decision in what weapons to equip my troops with, but that's just me.   All that being said, these issues were fixed in an absolutely beautiful mod called 'Long War', but since this mod is also extremely difficult, you'll need to do at least a couple playthroughs of the vanilla game before moving up.   Don't take away that XCOM is bad, because it's absolutely amazing, and between the time I've spent playing on here and on my old Xbox, it's easily one of my most played games of all time. There are a couple issues, yes, but they can be fixed when you're good enough to handle Long War and even before that, they're never dealbreakers. Please get this game, you owe it to yourself.

This is not a game I recommend for the weak of heart (or the salty for that matter). It is a great game allowing for hours upon hours of entertainment. For a fan of turn-based strategy games this is (in my honest opinion) a must-buy. Back to my original statement; this game will do anything it can to screw you over. You WILL miss important shots, enemies WILL hit dangerous shots, the game WILL introduce enemies at horrible times, it WILL put your best units in the sickbed when you need them. This game loves to taste your salt, be it through tears or ragequits. But beating a mission without anyone dying after the game seemingly did everything in its power to kill them all is really satisfying. I recommend starting on easy, even if you're familiar with turn-based strategy games. You don't want to be too horribly screwed by the enemies before you know anything about them.  -Good things- Unit classes which are all varied with different skills to bring, really fun to play around with some skill sets and combos. Winning a map can be very satisfying. Bit of base management which is good for relieving the stress combat brings. Solid replayability (coming partly from something I'll get to). You can customize your units' appearance.  -Bad things- The base game has a tendancy to break, at some points the game simply froze with nothing to do but close it and load a save (if available), I have not encountered this (to my memory) with the expansion. When you run out of money or other resources for the base building there's nothing active you can do, all you can do is wait for something to happen. Some enemies can ruin your day by just showing up on the map, being most of the later enemies (Floater being the first to come to mind), this can work to the game's advantage with replayability though: many times that I start a new game is because I miss the pre-Sectopod period.  I also recommend getting Enemy Within: the aliens it adds are a bit weak, but everything else it adds makes it worth every penny.

This game is like crack Like really, its hard to stop once you start. XCOM is basically Final Fantasy Tactics with aliens and guns.   STORY- 3/5 Oh noo all the people in the city are dead, lets bankrupt all the countries in the world to create and fund an alien combat organization. Then when you need funding (Which is pretty much always), any country you didn't help during an invasion will get butthurt and bail out of XCOM resulting in less cash and less love from your bosses.  (Fun Fact: Did you know we transmit radio signals from Earth in order to make contact with other life? Did you also know that every time a more advanced civilization comes across a more primitive one, they kill and pillage the hell out of them. I wonder which one we are?)  GRAPHICS- Meh/5 Not really realistic, yet the art style of XCOM (aliens, guns, maps, etc) is unique. It manages to look a little cartoony, but still awesome in every way. Even if the plasma sniper rifle looks like a glowing green ♥♥♥♥♥.  SOUNDTRACK- 5/5 The music is so good I do hardcore stuff while listening (Ex. Washing the dishes, going for a brisk jog, creeping on people on Facebook)  GAMEPLAY- 4/5 If I don't save after each turn, I usually lose half my squad by the end of the mission.     Pros-  -The Alien Autopsy scenes are wicked!  -Squad based tactics is the bomb  -Soldiers level up and gain essential skills/perks respective to each class   -Skills/Perks are set where when you level up, you can only pick one of two (All the abilities can play a pivotal role in the development of how you want to play a class (Wanna make SGT Pedro a billy badass Assault Trooper? Teach him Rapid Fire so you can laugh while he decimates aliens up close. Want more map control? Teach him Flush and he can shoot at enemy cover forcing them to run the ♥♥♥♥♥es they are! But you can only have one or the other since both skills are presented at the rank Lieutenant)  -You can literally make your dream team with the character customization (I made a Mr. T clone before he got destroyed by some big guys)  -Armor diversity is good (Cloaking, jetpacks, and mechsuits oh my!)  -The dead stay dead   Cons-  -The dead stay dead  -The interface with moving your units can be tricky at first  -Civilians like to get killed before you can save them  -Lack of weapon diversity (New weapons researched just offer more damage. They could have added more weapons that could allow for more strategies instead of just flanking and hiding behind cars that can explode)   CONCLUSION- Go buy it now you cheapskate

I've been playing the first UFO back in 1994 and loved the approach in mixing resource management strategy with a tactics game. What put me off were the frequent and rather long battles, coupled with an input system that drove you nuts, especially when you had to switch between levels. At some point I had to give up. because it wasn't fun to fight 20 battles without having any idea if the game is actually progressing or not.  The remake did adress all the aforementioned problems. You actually have a steady game progression wich is tied to the narration of the plot. Controls are intuitive and allow a flawless execution of your ideas.  There are a few things left wanting, though. The difficulty ranges between stupidly easy and deadlock situations, in which you save and load over and over to have the lucky roll you need to survive the first enemy initiatve attack. But most of the time it is sufficient to advance slowly in a coherent fire line to blow the enemies to pieces. But well, I could live with that, although I didn't really feel like having to worry about tactics too much.  Another tings is the missed opportunity to add some personality to your squad members. They are just some exchangeable, generic action figures without any personal background, distinctive traits or anytihng else that would make you feel care about their fate. But then, I'm still waiting for a worthy successor for Jagged Alliance 2, so I guess that's too much to wish for atm.  Recommended for fans of the old X-COM games. Die hard fans of tactic games might be disappointed by the rather simple combat gameplay.  Wait for a sale like I did, then try it out. I for my part probably won't replay it, I didn't even feel motivated to continue with the addon.

All n all it's pretty fun but looking at Xcom 2 it's turning into silliness now with geurilla warfare and snakehead aliens and gasp swords!! lol Xcom meet Alien Creed. :)  ENEMY WITHIN on the other hand is a piece of crap. An (almost) perfect successor to the original X-Com series.  - Bases. You can only have one. Multiple base management was a huge part of the original games. - Base defense. Because you don't have the option to build more bases this feature was non-existant in the base game. - Squad size. Limited to 6. No more massed infantry, this is a bit more tactical than the original because of it, but it loses a bit of 'fun' having such a small squad. - Very little inventory management. A large part of the combat in the original was managing your guys inventory. It's very basic here. - Enemies come in 'packs' that get a free movement phase as soon as you uncover them. No finding a lone guy out on the side and killing him before he can get to cover in this.  In spite of these flaws, it's still an unbelivably good game, and I would recommend it to anyone.

First, let me start off by saying: this is a great, great game. Lots of time and experience (think the King of Strategy: Sid Meir) went into this game, and while there are some visual bugs, it's quite pretty and eery at times (although the envirorments are not continent-specific whatsover; sometimes you kind of chuckle when you're dropped into a jungle in the middle of Egypt). It's also hard; really, really flippin' hard. I would venture to say that in my short span of gaming, this is the hardest game I've played. I'm a casual gamer, granted, but this game...it has infuriated me beyond any other game I've played. It's fun! Really, it's a 'one more turn/one more match/holy crap it's four AM' kind of game, and the story line really makes you push yourself (sometimes too quickly) to advance. But it's really hard. Now, I actually DO recommend this game - to gamers really good at strategy and tactics (AKA NOT ME). But for the casual gamer who has maybe five hours a week max to sit down and game, this is NOT the game to play. It's honestly ruined a few nights for me because I've had to keep restarting to beat one level - and that's on easy. Okay, so odds are I suck (95% sure of that). But that doesn't mean I'm wrong. That's also one of the beautiful things of the game, especially when you put Ironman mode on (automatic saves, perma-deaths). It really makes you take ever turn, every decision, every research and engineering project seriously. But it's just really flippin' hard, and as a gamer who wants to be slightly challenged, not frustrated, and experience a good story line, this game doesn't do it. Also, it’s hard in some dumb ways - your guys are gonna miss A LOT of seemingly-super easy shots, only to get murdered the next round. So, summed up: it's a great game, even two years later - but it's hard, and while I got it for free via a promotion, I would never spend actual money on this game that has visibly upset me for a good few days now. If you feel up to it, by all means go for it. You might find it worth it. As for me, I'm shelfing it and moving on.

The best soldiers in the world, wielding cutting-edge weaponry and armor deployed to France. A UFO had landed there, and brought with it a full contingent of alien troopers. The battle raged from the landing zone all the way to the UFO itself. An injured Muton retreated inside the UFO whilst my elite warriors mopped up the remaining survivors in the treeline.  Wave after wave of Xray scum crashed against my troops, trying desperately to resist, but they were no match for the advanced tactics of my troops. We pressed onward, seizing the interior of the alien craft itself, until we cornered the wounded muton. FIghting back with the terrible savagery of a cornered bear, he lobbed plasma shell after plasma shell onto my troops.   It was as though he knew I had yet to capture a live specimen of his species for study.   Through the use of smoke grenades and first aid I was able to recuperate the damage he had dealt to my warriors' minds and bodies. It would not be easy to subdue this beast, but a plan was devised. The majority of the squad would cover the hallway so that he could not retreat further into his ship. Two soldiers, one carrying the super-taser device and the other carrying a rocket launcher went around the outside. a hole would be blasted in the side of the ship, allowing for the quick subjugation of this fierce, elusive creature.  The soldiers took their positions.  The rocket was fired.  Through the fiery smoke and debris the brave soldier rushed in.  The beast turned around, angry and startled.  The device fired, sending a concentrated burst of electricity into the behemoth's body.  Stun failed.  Why RNGesus. Why.

Had to revise my previous review. I like XCom, don't get me wrong (and am looking forward to XCom 2) but I didn't like the Long War mod, one bit and it's a shame because it adds so much to it.  Xcom Enemy Unknown: 7/10, a pretty good games, which has a few gliches here and there but nothing breaking, although I'd given up on iron man matches because the occasional gliches can kill an entire game, when it forces a reload and loops.  Xcom Enemy Within: 9/10, just love the additional content, which adds so much to the original. The cynic in me wonders why the hell this wasn't shipped with the original if not to screw more dollars out the player ffs but I'll ignore it and put it down to a hard-working team, who continued to work on it after release and took the uncomfortable decision to put a price on it because of the amount of work that went into it.  Long War: 6/10. Now I know this is a free mod and I'm not stamping my feet or anything like that, I'm just simply saying that overall, after some time playing it, I felt that the minuses considerably outweighed the plusses. Don't get me wrong, I liked the additional difficulty and improved tactical play of the aliens, the more technical outlook of air combat, research and basically the whole approach to the game. What I didn't like and this is the game breaker for me - one-on-one, for the most part, the aliens will hit you more than you hit them in a straight-up gun-line firefight, which forces you to try to outflank and collapse their line. This is all well and good and I had no problem with that but the fact that you are considerably outnumbered and the operational theatre is quite small results in your outflanking force being outflanked purely because there isn't enough room in the OT to accommodate your outlfanking without running into another pack of aliens who are on a guard loop. You are therefore forced to just try your luck, which will have cataclismic consequences if your outflankers hit another squad or ride out the gun-line fight and accept the casualties and hope your squad doesn't get ground down before your clear out the level. Shame really.

If you like turn-based strategy at all, don't miss out on this gem. The graphics are easy on the eye and gameplay is intuitive despite the learning curve. For those familiar with the X-COM series, this installment definitely takes a more player-friendly approach when it comes to difficulty than the classic X-COM games. Beware though, overly ambitious playing style is usually punished. And sometimes luck simply turns against you. But in general it feels a lot more fair than the classics.  I would have liked the base management a litle more fleshed out and some of the encounters felt repetetive after a while (UFO crash landed, go in and kill the same old enemies over and over). But this is nothing that gets in the way of the sense of achievement when gloriously taking out a large group of heavily armed foes by well thought out tactics and returning home without a scratch. The game does a great job at creating a challenge by limiting the player's resources and options in a smart way. Do you buy those new rifles or save up for better satelite coverage?   If you don't own this game and gunning down some aliens by using your brain over your reflexes sounds like your cup of tea, go ahead and buy it already. It's really as good as they say. If you prefer fast paced RTS, shooters or highly complex simulations, this is probably not your game.

ayyliums get free turns when spotted, every time anyone does anything there's a horribly long animation to watch, cover doesn't actually do anything tangible, and you will miss pretty much every shot you try to make while the enemy will almost never miss theirs in the early game. in the late game, the reverse is true; you have armor and perks that completely negate anything's chance to be a threat anymore, and the enemies actually lose things they had earlier in the game that were so threatening.  actually very much unlike the original in terms of difficulty since it's not so much hyper-lethal on all sides and generally unforgiving as it just outright cheats and all your decisions are utterly meaningless, assuming the game isn't too busy with the same animation you've seen a hundred times to respond to your keyboard inputs  it's riddled with bugs and design issues. so far I've encountered: * Object hiding is completely insane and basically doesn't work. Sloped roofs never hide. Multiple-floor buildings generally hide all at once if there's objects of interest on more than one floor, making it difficult to manage soldiers on different elevations.  * Grenade/Rocket HUD does not accurately show what environmental objects will be hit and destroyed.  * Characters can move into or out of grenade/rocket explosions in real time, because it's based on real radius and not tiles occupied. Thus, depending on what animation a character is doing, they can dodge an explosion that should have hit or be hit by an explosion they were clear of a literal second ago.  * 'Missed' shots can still pass hit characters, complete with blood effects. At least it doesn't do damage!  * 100% to-hit shots can still be missed if they somehow don't connect with the enemy in question. This will fail to do damage.  * The skyranger sometimes just doesn't land at XCom HQ. It'll be shown moving on the geoscape world map, but the game will be soft-locked at this point and you have to Alt-F4. (The pause menu is not usable.)  * Combat Stims straight up do not work. Item is not depleted when used, and does not confer any benefits when used. It still takes a round-ending action to try, though.  * VIPs in escort missions can be killed before you have control of them. This is hopefully unintended behaviour.  * Soemtimes, escort missions will give control over civilians who aren't the VIP to escort. If these civilians die, the mission will fail. They are not targeted if you don't have control over them, but aliens will try to kill them if you do have control. (Oddly enough, they count as VIPs and will end the mission if you escort a body guard or generic soldier to the escape zone instead of the prescribed VIP.)  * Enemy groups don't move on lines, and just teleport from point to point. Because of this, enemy groups can teleport to closer range than where the fog ends, making for bizarre overwatch behaviours and easy flanking/point blank shots for them after being activated if you don't kill the whole group immediately.  * Enemy groups can activate such that one or more members of the group will phase through a wall. Occasionally, they will phase into normally inaccessable areas, such as the insides of shipping containers or closed rooms without doors/windows. In these cases, if you don't have explosives, the mission is effectively impossible to complete as the alien cannot leave the space and you cannot breach it to kill the alien.  * Enemy airdropped troops can land directly inside your soldiers. Oddly, shots on aliens that are occupying the same tile as you are counted as being pretty far away (but not infinitely far) and will generally have a mediocre aim chance instead of the 100% you usually get from point-blank shots.  * Destroyed cover objects generate fog of war where they were. This fog takes real time to clear; a shot that seemingly broke LOS by interfering with peeking behaviour on full-cover objects usually just made the game confused, and not doing anything for a minute or two of real time will bring the alien back into view. When this happens on alien turns, the enemy stops moving until the glitched fog clears.  * Enemies in cover who have their cover destroyed often retain the cover state they were last in when the cover was destroyed for several real-time moments, similar to above.  * Overwatch shots made by aliens have a tendency to make the camera linger on nothing of note. May also be related to above.  * Soldiers may have the HUD note that they can see an alien, but trying to select 'Fire' or any similar action says that there is nothing in range. Sometimes waiting real time will fix the problem and make the supposedly seen alien able to be fired upon, but not every time.  * Left-clicking a door occasionally causes the soldier to charge through the door and stand in the doorframe instead of quietly opening the door from the side.  *The perk Rapid Reaction sometimes fails, and the Heavy will not get a second reaction fire opportunity despite hitting the first overwatch shot on an approaching enemy.  * Putting a SHIV in front of a door breaks the door forever, and makes each tile on boths sides of the door impassable terrain.  * Open doors sometimes become impassable terrain when loading a save made during a mission.  * Fire occasionally clears or spreads in the middle of a turn, making a space impassible one moment and passable again the next.  * Thin Man poison generates on the corpse in real space much like explosions, with many of the same bugs. Women are better at not getting poisoned just because their models are smaller so they have less of a chance of being hit by a random particle!  * Dense Smoke is insanely GPU-taxing for no clear reason. Several normal smokes in the same space run fine, but a single Dense Smoke tanks the framerate. Oddly, Combat Drugs smoke is less taxing than normal smoke despite having more particles to draw (it includes blue flakes in addition to the normal smoke)  * Hitting a Muton Berserker and causing it to move on the player turn makes the game stutter very severely for no clear reason.  * Berserkers rarely trigger Close Combat Specialist's free Overwatch strike, but sometimes do. Seems to do with their intent to melee.  * Close Combat Specialist can trigger multiple times. It also triggers when movement begins within the 4 tile radius, such as an enemy panicking and attempting to flee from your CCS-having soldier. Not sure if that's intended.  * Skeleton Suit and Ghost Armor grappling sometimes fails. The action is spent and the animation plays, but the charcater then teleport to their original position and the tile they attempted to grapple to becomes impassable terrain for the remainder of the round. If this triggers on the last action of the turn, the soldier gets a 'free' actions back (though the HUD won't show a pip denoting the action is available), but if it was the first action, it is completely wasted. Soldiers who can fire without spending an action (e.g. In The Zone sniping, activating Run&Gun, etc) can do so normally before doing anything that would consume the action.  * Cars and other explosive objects can catch fire and explode, and then be set aflame again and explode again even though they've already exploded.  * Overwatch sometimes fails, leaving the soldier unable to use any abilities (including basic Fire, Hunker Down, etc.) but somehow retaining actions. They can move, but not do anything else.  * Overwatch sometimes fails, consuming the action and leaving the soldier supposedly in overwatch, but aliens can run directly across their view and the soldier will not even attempt a reaction shot.  *Starting the game without an audio device installed and active (i.e. your headphones/speakers are unplugged or off for whatever reason) will cause the game to never have audio for that session.  And that's just the bugs.  10/10

30$ plus 30 more to fix the game with an expansion is way too much for a unfair three years old unpredictable tactic RPG.  Here the long version  This game has ENORMOUS game design flaws that makes this TACTIC RPG unpredicatable, the encounter system forces you into extreme caution and creates boring gameplay. Also, this game's UI and engine are super buggy. Most of the problems can be fixed by a 30$ expansion, but the bugs aren't patched in the regular game.  First of, the difficulty is artificial. This game is not hard if you know what you're doing, but RNG makes it unpredictable. Sometimes you miss 95% shots. It happens and is not inhenrently bad game design. What is bad game design is when you cannot prepare in a tactic RPG. Sometimes enemies just spawn next to you and uses overwatch, which means your first priority is to kill that enemy because he prevents you from repositionning safely. But when that enemy dies, he explodes into a poison cloud on one of your unit that you could not move without getting shot and killed. There are plenty of those unpredictable situations that makes the game smiply unfair instead of difficult.  The way you encounter enemies is also very flawed. Since you are very vulnerable to aliens because there is very little full cover (at least in Enemy Unknown), you advance very, very slowly, which creates boring missions. If you don't move slowly, you encounter several alien groups in one turn and they simply kill you. Sometimes alien run into you during their turns, at which point they are given another turn to reposition because aliens do not have good enough AI to move from cover to cover in the fog of war. This si not a huge problem, but it still creates this impression that the game is cheating you. Sometimes, during the aliens' turn, multiple groups of them walks in your line of sight. This creates situations in which you are at a clear disadvantage only because of the game's RNG.  The UI is extremely buggy and lacking. First of, you cannot know what your soldiers are able to shoot before moving. This forces you to take moves without knowing what follow ups are possible afterwards. The lack of indication on your line of sight (and the aliens' line of sight) makes it that you have to GUESS in a TACTIC RPG, which is exactly what you are trying to prevent in this genre of games. You cannot take the less risky move if the game lacks a UI that indicates what the safest move is. Sometimes, parts of the UI don't load, which leaves you waiting 10 seconds for the max distance of a soldier's move to load. When you shoot a rocket or a smoke grenade, the game shows you a sphere to indicate the range of the explosion. That sphere is lying. The range is actually a bit smaller than what it shows you, which can result in you wasting ressources because of the terrible UI.  This game has a weird way to show the results of its RNG calculations into the engine. Sometimes, you miss, then the game shows you shooting into the alien's shoulder three times and tells you you missed. Sometimes you shoot trough ally soldiers or walls, without breaking the walls, etc.  I think the worst about this game is how most of these UI problems are fixed through the game's expansion, Enemy Within. The 30$ patch provides other gameplay elements, but, most importantly, it fixes issues with the original game. For exemple, rockets indicators now changes to red everthing that will be damaged by the explosion. This is nice, sure, but these changes were not patched into the regular game. This basically makes Enemy Within a paid patch and renders this game alone a TERRIBLE value proposition.

Here's why I love this game: Jose 'Whiskey' Guzman.  Jose 'Whiskey' Guzman doesn't exist, but I will never forget him. My support trooper, he was the backbone of my X-Com team. He ran more missions than anyone else on the team and saved the lives of just about everyone at least once, popping smoke and deploying medkits. He was more than a medic- he had 54 confirmed kills and was a crack shot with a plasma rifle.   On his 28th mission the team hit heavy resistance securing a downed UFO. After tense fighting against elite troops that left half the team wounded, a mech that we'd never seen appeared. This big ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ put two plasma rounds into our MEC trooper, critically wounding him. Whiskey sprinted to his side and stabilized him, saving his life. Afterward he tried to sprint to Carol 'Spider' Stevens, our wounded sniper, to pop a medkit on her. Passing a doorway the mech unexpectedly got an open shot on him, and put two rounds clean through his midsection. He died instantly.   I play on Ironman, which means no quickloading, and losing him hit me like I've rarely ever been hit by a game. I even thought about him the next day at work. In X-Com, every decision counts and death is permanent. Your squad members that survive and develop over many missions become something special, and when you lose one it can be absolutely devastating.   That sort of emotional investment is why I play games, and I can't recommend this one enough!   10/10

It was raining. Corporal Mayweather adjusted the sights on her laser sniper. It was pretty fancy but she almost preferred the standard issue rifle, not this alien junk. She hated them. It was still hard to believe this was even happening: aliens, abductions, death. It was all she knew now. For the last 6 months she jumped from mission to mission. Quickly falling into the role of squad sharpshooter. Her lightning reflexes and dead aim kept the others alive, and she could never take her job seriously enough. This particular day they had been flown to Germany to invetigate a downed UFO, a milk run, command had said. She was beginning to doubt it. The squad leader had her positioned on a ridge, providing overwatch to her comrades below, and watch she did. Suddenly out of the corner of her eye she saw them. Three sectoids. Thats what the scientists called them. They had that 'classic' alien look to them and they carried plasma rifles attached to their wrists. She alerted the rest of her squad and they took up position. Stevens ran up to the ridge and took cover behind a stump. 'You all set up there?' he asked. Mayweather looked down and gave a nod, her bright purple hair soaked and matted on her head. Stevens was the squad medic and she had taken a particular liking to him. He was always quick to run in the line of fire and rescue a downed squadmate or provide moral support. The sectoids approached cautiously, and as they closed in a few shots rang out from the east. It was the rookie, Himata. He had panicked and taken a few shots at the sectoids, but was nowhere near his target. Mayweather shot a glare in his general direction, but she remembered how it was during her first mission. The poor guy could barely keep himself alert and mentally intact. Wait... Had she heard those noises before? The downed UFO echoed something fierce and suddenly three Floaters shot out of the hangar bay. She had a few confirmed floater kills from previous missions and she knew they were a force to be reckoned with. Her training and reflexes kicked in and she snapped a quick shot at the nearest floater. As it always did, the shot connected with a crisp burning sound and the floater dropped, lifeless, to the ground. The other two quickly hovered into positions and began their counter attack. Their heavy plasma rifles flashed in a series of shots that seemed to casually drift not to her, no. Stevens was their target. Desperate not to lose him she shouted: 'STEVENS GET DOWN!' He was hit, badly. She jumped down from the ridge and ran to his side, struggling to give him any kind of cover. 'Mayweather, what are you doing!' It was the seargent, he sympathized with her but he knew she was their only chance at getting out of this mission alive. 'Get back on overwatch!' She was torn, conflicting emotions tumbling around inside her. She looked down at Stevens and as their gaze connected two things happened. First: she realized what stevens would have her do, he wanted her to do her job, to kill those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that had caused the human race so much pain. The second thing that happened was that a plasma shot from a previously unseen sectoid came flying through the air straight at Stevens. Time seemed to slow as it lazily drifted into the side of his head and continued onwards, as if the human life it had just taken didn't phase it at all. Even though her sights were muddled from the tears, Mayweather stood and took her shot. The sectoid fell, then another, and another. Her thoughts lost in a cloud of rage, she let loose and gave the aliens what they deserved. Justice wasn't as simple as paying them back, and it was small compensation for what they had taken from her, because she knew none of her missions would be the same again.     There is enough emotional material in this game to write a million books.  10/10 would become amateur author again.

( This is coming from a person that was NEVER into turn based games. ) Written in a win-win perspective.   This game is fantastic.  The graphics are good for the time, enemies are unique and constantly changing, and as a bonus, the game actually requires you to THINK to get the best performance out of any mission. Currency managing is a must, as doing so will reward you when something bad DOES happen.  Breakdown:  Pro(s) +Good graphics. (Customizable for higher-end PC's like mine.) +Smart enemy AI - It WILL kill you if you don't pay attention! +As your forces get better, they can be customized to fill the role that you want them to fill. +Has a very interesting mechanic of researching and constructing facilities to further your 'Rush to the top!' +Story is..Well..Interesting! It won't bore you to death, if you're into that kind of thing. +Overall a well made game. Enemy within Significantly adds to the game, and fixes some annoying bugs, too. +Really nice customization. Especially the customization DLC 'Elite soldier' which gives you some sweet power-ranger lookin' crap.  Cons: -After a while, the aliens begin advancing so damn fast, that it's mentally straining to know that it will only get worse. ( At first, this is 100% OK, keeps you interested and won't allow you to become overpowered. BUT, eventually, it just gets ridiculous..) -Some pretty annoying state-of-the-art bugs. (Honestly? You can easily look right past them, so it's all good. ) -System can often screw you violently. A 90% shot can miss really easily. (Realism. Realism hurts.. ) -Some aliens are outright overpowered no matter what you upgrade. (Ok at early stages - Later becomes annoying, as you know 'Okay I'm definetly going to get one guy seriously injured after this.. )   Middle:  -/+ System can and WILL cheat you, with insane amounts of aliens to fight at once. (This, again, is okay at the early stages. But eventually - - It's too much to handle, no matter how advanced your guys are. ) -/+ The maps repeat. ( This is kind of OK, as you become familiar with maps and learn the best tactical approuch to overcome odds at them. ) -/+ Aliens advance just like you. (Is okay at early stages - But they can and WILL start advancing 3x as fast as you, and suddenly, out of the blue, have MANY, new, powerful units. ) -/+ The 'Will' stat on soldiers. (While this is reasonable, sometimes, it makes you want to bash your head in with a rock. You'd think a soldier's will would seriously increase if you win - But no, this game pretty much says 'This, this is your soldier's will. THIS is how it will stay-, and annoy the hell out of you when one of them panics randomly because their will is slightly lower than the next guy. OR, worst case, gets mind controlled because of it. Really annoying, but I guess understandable. )   Overall: 8/10. Very good, and very fun. Early stages become fun, while keeping the difficulty up there. Later stages..Well, become significantly more annoying to deal with and overcome.

Such as attacking an enemy, or setting up cover fire, throwing a grenade, etc.  You are also in command of the main base where your soldiers are housed and all the technology and weapons come from. As you progress in the game you are given currency to spend on makeing facilities, building armor or weapons, and also building aircrafts to protect the skies with as well. Depending on how well you do in the missions you can also gain access to various research options which will allow you to make better upgrades for your soldiers or aircrafts you make.  This game can become highly addictive, and if you play each mission very cautiously like I did you will end up finding yourself watching the hours go by as you become immersed within the game. The difficulty is definitely toned down from the classic games (where one bad RNG roll could get half your squad wiped out on their first move) but that doesn't make it easy.  This game features a focused tech tree which will let you make a few interesting choices without keeping you from fully exploring it, fun turn-based tactical combat, customizable options for your soldiers, and a variety of enemies. Each enemy species has its own general tactics, and even the easiest of them can be dangerous.  Overall, a fun game. One of the coolest turn-based games around, XCOM puts you in control of your own elite squad of alien-blasting soldiers.  You start off with just a handful of soldiers in a small base, eliminating aliens as they land (or crash) their ships onto the planet, abduct civilians or just plain terrorising everyone. Every country you gain funding from improves your chances to get new weapons and units to kick the arses of new, heavily armoured or psychic aliens. A variety of missions are available after a few hours, and this is where the fun begins.  The game focuses on turn-based squad strategy. Placing units behind objects for cover, using weapons and abilities to eliminate hostile forces is crucial, while trying not to get killed along the way. Key tip: you are expected to lose lots of squad members throughout your playthrough, maybe even losing funding from a country, but it's okay - that's how XCOM works.  The artwork is nothing to behold, honestly, but some of the designs for the aliens and mechs are pretty cool.
