A word of warning: you will lose many hours into the night getting absorbed into this. I've never played the original, so unfortunately I can't make comparisons with earlier games - but seeing this as a standalone, I've found this to be a very addictive (and challenging enough, even at normal difficulty) turn-based strategy game. The pace of battle is taking cover and moving in slow, deliberated steps at a time while taking care not to expose your flanks in various environments, using the debris and buildings you have at disposal for your ingenuity. If Game's Workshop were to make a Necromunda game for PC, I would look at this as a starting template. Managing your base (a vague similarity to Evil Genius echos, but without boobytraps) is an extra factor to deal with when you're not on the battlefield. Researching, upgrading, building ships to stave off UFO invasions and making decisions with consequences are many of things you need to budget for with your limited funding at disposal. A (small) particular upside I like is that you can customise the look and names for your squad members - but it does make it harder to accept when you lose them in battle. A (small) downside is with the customisation - there isn't enough faces, races, hair, etc. to play around with. Overall - you could probably play this game, one battle at a time and put it away and come back to it the next day (for all us full-timers out there, stuck at the grindstone), but chances are, you will lose sleep with that 'just one more battle and then I'm done' kind of attitude.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is one of the best games I've played in the recent years. It seamlessly combines tactical RPG and resource management while providing with a decent, interesting story and a setting full of surprises to discover. Everything about this game is solid : the combats are thrilling and engaging, the base building / management part is very well balanced and the whole formula is addicting. You might find yourself waiting for one more mission, one more upgrade to your weaponry, one more science lab discovery.  The best part about the game is how unforgiving it can be. Soldiers die easily in this game, especially early on. You may lose many good men in your first few missions, but those who survive will thrive on the battlefield : they will be your heroes, the pillars of your teams... until they fall, too. One big mistake can lead to a character's doom, no matter how far you are in the game. XCOM manages to make progression feel truly meaningful while never allowing you to ignore the risks of a mission. For extra fun, use the character editor to make your soldiers look like your real-life friends, rename them and try to keep them alive as long as possible.  I recommend the expansion, for it fixes the only true issue I had with the base game : the very limited amount of maps. Enemy Within adds a lot of new battlefields, which makes missions very unpredictable and fresh. It adds amazing new concepts such as mechanical soldiers in giant steel suits and genetically modified super soldiers and also has you fighting human enemies that are often much more crafty and dangerous than the aliens you usually confront. It's a great expansion that improves on nearly everything.  If you're not afraid of a hard game that rewards progress as much as it punishes you for your mistakes, I think XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a game for you.

Okay, where to start with this... Being a fan of Jagged Aliance 2, I have seen several elements from that series that was implemented here, with some alternative twists to it (IE no real time inbetween encounters, no overworld map where mercs/troops in squads have to march around on foot, no REAL stealth mechanics, and no Queen Dedrianna ♥♥♥♥♥ slapping her bad-news advisor, Eliot). Some of these changes are good, some of them are bad.  Most of the issues I've seen are graphical and animation based: soldiers sometimes shoot through walls rather than actually trying to twist around them to shoot at enemies. This provides some humorous moments and some wtf moments as it combines with the rag doll physics that have been employed.  The most irritating issue though is that of the movement and aiming grenades features. To put it frankly, there are so many levels of terrain and the grid is so case sensitive that it winds up twitching between one cell and another. This would not be a problem if it didn't lead to my soldier getting no cover, or that sight scanner from the sniper some how going through the ceiling and on to the roof of an alien space craft.  Also, what is highly annoying is the first time you play the game, it forces you to go through a tutorial that gives you a pretty nasty cruch. 3 out of the 4 soldiers that get sent in at the start are pretty much guaranteed to die. Thankfully it does not force you to repeat this tutorial of death after you've done it once. They also force you to start in America the first time, which leads you to wind up only with cost decreases in the aircraft department... not useful at all for the first playthrough.  Then the final issue is occasionally this mission requirements reminder pops up upon return to the main facilities and it won't really go away until you A) save the game, go to the main menu, and load it up again. or B) some how manage to get it to allow you to take another mission and send your troops off; it will remove it when you go to the battle scenario. This also adds for some confusion as occasionally it'll try to select a facility rather than pay attention to your click on the tabs at the top right of the screen. There is also a bit of an issue with the damn people randomly speaking to you while your in the facilities and giving you an unskippable line, but thats a minor issue, as you can still some what navigate and work using those tabs I spoke of.  ... Thats all the negatives through with. Now, what I can say is despite all of these issues, I have gotten some entertainment value and had some fun with this game. Is it perfect? No, nothing is, I plan on trying to see if there are patches or something for these issues that I spoke of. Is it worth buying? I think it is, provided you find a way to get around the control issues (you should find that turning the map really does help in this department, though you might still hit the occasional throwing something through the ceiling if you have to try and raise the view a little bit so you can actually see what your trying to hit and prevent these issues).  I give it a 7.8 out of 10.

As someone that grew up playing the original UFO and TFTD games (alongside other Turn-Based classics like the Jagged Alliance franchise), the genre will always have a special place in my little gaming heart. I was both optimistic and hesitant when I heard about a franchise reboot for XCOM-- excited, of course, but would it live up to the gold standard already carved out by its predecessors?  Make no mistake, the core gameplay *concepts* are all present and accounted for, but the mechanics have changed. XCOM now concerns itself with one central HQ, removing the need to micromanage several different bases. Radar coverage is replaced with remote satellites, and each continent is nice enough to allow you some hangar slots to police the airspace. Within the battlescape, your squaddies now perform two 'actions' per turn, as opposed to the traditional TU system. Move, fire, sprint and a handful of unique abilities replace the classic system I grew up with, and it's... different. Admittedly, I had a little culture shock when I first jumped in, but I feel like it's a case where change really can be a positive thing. My hesitation about the new system faded even within my first session-- it's a genuinely intuitive set of mechanics that very quickly grew on me.  All things considered, my optimism paid off. If you're like me and harbor a classical love of the genre, don't miss out. It's a different game, but I can't put it any more simply than this: The game is a legitimate credit to the franchise, and with the flair of a more modern look and feel, it truly lives up to the XCOM name.

Awesome game.  A a few decades after the first X-COM game, Enemy Unknown takes us back to turn-based strategy with mastery. The strategy elements are well balanced and the plot is reasonable at least, with some great individual moments. You have to balance both micro-managing a combat squad in ground missions and strategically planning your research projects and finances.  In the end, the fun happens in the combat missions, where you will fight off aliens attacking civilians, strke their bases, swipe UFO's you shot down and even defend your own ground should they find you.  The long term planing, while not quite as dynamic as the combat missions, is equally important to guarantee your continued survivability. Chose whether to rush your research by adding laboratory may and you may risk not having enough satelite coverage to prevent the aliens from dominating whole nations. Chose the other way around and you risk being greatly overpowered in the long run. This is just one a great deal of strategical choices you will have to make.  The plot, while not a shining masterpiece in itself, is true to its origins and provides great immersion. You are trusted with the decisions on how humanity will fight off the threat of impending exctinction caused by an alien invasion. If you are a fan of the original game, expect to see pretty much everything in this re-enacting. If you are not, then you have a lot of content to explore.  Here's how I'd summarize the ups and downs of this game:  Pro's:  1. Can be challenging at the right difficulty setting. 2. Respects the original game's formula for a balanced TBS experience. 3. Has good replayability value.  Con's:  1. Fails to replicate the tense atmosphere of the original game. 2. Can get a little repetitive without the expansion.  Overal 90/100 without the expansion, 95/100 with it.  *The reason I add 5 points for the expansion is because it adds good variations of combat missions, lots of customization options and new content never before seen in the franchise, adds a lot of new variables to the combat missions, and it all works to improve the overall strategy experience and mitigate some repetitive scenarios of the original game.

XCOM is a turn-based strategy game with tactical battles where you command a secret organization tasked with defending Earth from an alien invasion. As you kill the aliens, you take their technology and repurpose it to use against them. XCOM is a remake of a very popular old DOS game, and this is the first XCOM game since then to stay in the same genre.  XCOM is very good, but it's far from perfect. The strategic base management is fun, but I would've liked a bit more. The battles were tough and engaging, but they are long and too frequent. Poor controls and camera really hurt the battle system. The story is also far too short for a game of this length. But, this game is still tons of fun, and the situations that emerge through normal gameplay can make for some great stories on their own.  As flawed as the game is, though, it's still a top-notch strategy title. Not many companies are still making games like this, and I'm grateful that Firaxis still puts out amazing strategy titles. Fans of strategy games will love XCOM.  Update: XCOM: Enemy Within has been out for a bit now, and it's definitely worth mentioning. Enemy Within is a full expansion pack that adds the ability to build mech pilots and use gene modifications to give you some more abilities to use. Enemy Within doesn't fix what was wrong with the original, but it improves upon XCOM's strengths. At the very least, I'm much more confident giving this game a recommendation to anyone that's interested in a fun but slow strategy game.

XCOM:Enemy Unknown has quickly become one of my favorite turn-based strategy games in a while. It is incredibly fun and rewarding to build up a base as you see fit and equip soldiers with all kinds of weapons and armor as you give them orders in battle against alien invaders. The ability to customize your soldiers' names and appearances was a nice touch that can help make the game seem more personal or can be used to make it more silly. You are given a reasonable amount of freedom to deal with the alien threat however you choose. Do you choose to focus on researching armor for your soldiers first? Or do you want to focus on your interceptors? Maybe you want to spend your money on another satellite and forego building that Laser Rifle for the time being. The choice is yours. The recent expansion, XCOM: Enemy Within, added a number of new and extremely fun features including base invasions, mechanized soldiers, and genetically modified soldiers. These add a new level of depth that make the game even more fun. The replayability of the single player of this game is endless due to the various difficulties, Ironman Mode, and a number of modifiers Firaxis has included to alter the game slightly. That being said, the game isn't without flaws. There are a number of minor bugs specifically UI related. At times it is difficult to tell where your cursor is, especially on stages where there a number of different levels to the stage (like the roof of a building), which can lead to some frustrating situations when your soldiers end up going someplace you didn't want them to (especially in Ironman mode!). The RNG can be frustrating and feel unfair at times, but, hey, that's the nature of RNG, isn't it? Overall, the game is absolutely terrific and is a must-buy for anyone into sci-fi and/or turn-based strategy games! 9/10.

Firaxis has done a fine job with XCOM. Though the general strategy and base-management portions of the game are handled adequately, It's the tactical battles that are this game's strength. Fans of turn-based tactics games like Fire Emblem and Tactics Ogre should feel right at home. This game is all about choice and mutual exclusivity; you'll never have the resources to do everything you want and the game offers an array of units that are all equally appealing in their own respects. There are always multiple via paths presented, and the game favors a patient and thoughtful approach. I love that.  The game's most glaring issue is the steep learning curve, which isn't the result of the game's difficulty so much as the fact that early on it does a poor job of explaining basic mechanics. It can take a little while to get your feet on the ground and if you're not picking things up fast enough on your own your first playthrough might be a wash. (Not a huge deal as the game is relatively short at 15-25 hours depending on difficulty.) Also, even after the November patch, this game still isn't entirely bug-free.  All in all, it's a solid game that offers a very enjoyable experience, but it's a little rough around the edges.

90%  XCOM puts you in the shoes of a base and battlefield commander, taking on missions around the globe with a team of 6 operatives to combat the unknown alien threat. It is equal parts turn-based strategy and base operations planning, the former being a glorious slugfest against ever increasingly potent enemies and the latter an easy to understand base set-up game that encourages planning ahead to maximize building adjacency bonuses and tech tree unlocks.  The game is infinitely replayable thanks to alternative upgrades, dozens of maps, mutators to the campaign, and variable difficulty modes that are mitigated somewhat by the ability to quick load a save every time an operative bites it.  Your choices on soldier abilities have impact because choosing one route usually locks out the other. You have limited funding and have to juggle weapons and armor production and research and base expansion.  With the upcoming Enemy Within expansion set to release, now is a great time for anyone who fancies turn-based action RPGs to hop in and see what the fuss is all about.

No one would have believed, in the last years of the nineteenth century, that human affairs were being watched from the timeless worlds of space.  No one could have dreamed we were being scrutinized, as someone with a microscope studies creatures that swarm and multiply in a drop of water. Few men even considered the possibility of life on other planets and yet, across the gulf of space, minds immeasurably superior to ours regarded this Earth with envious eyes, and slowly and surely, they drew their plans against us.  At midnight on the twelfth of August, a huge mass of luminous gas erupted from Mars and sped towards Earth. Across two hundred million miles of void, invisibly hurtling towards us, came the first of the missiles that were to bring so much calamity to Earth. As I watched, there was another jet of gas. It was another missile, starting on its way.  And that's how it was for the next ten nights. A flare, spurting out from Mars - bright green, drawing a green mist behind it - a beautiful, but somehow disturbing sight. Ogilvy, the astronomer, assured me we were in no danger. He was convinced there could be no living thing on that remote, forbidding planet.  'The chances of anything coming from Mars are a million to one,' he said. 'The chances of anything coming from Mars are a million to one - but still they come!'  Then came the night the first missile approached Earth. It was thought to be an ordinary falling star, but next day there was a huge crater in the middle of the Common, and Ogilvy came to examine what lay there: a cylinder, thirty yards across, glowing hot... and with faint sounds of movement coming from within.  Suddenly the top began moving, rotating, unscrewing, and Ogilvy feared there was a man inside, trying to escape. he rushed to the cylinder, but the intense heat stopped him before he could burn himself on the metal.  'The chances of anything coming from Mars are a million to one,' he said. 'The chances of anything coming from Mars are a million to one - but they still come!' 'Yes, the chances of anything coming from Mars are a million to one,' he said. 'The chances of anything coming from Mars are a million to one - but they still come!'  It seems totally incredible to me now that everyone spent that evening as though it were just like any other. From the railway station came the sound of shunting trains, ringing and rumbling, softened almost into melody by the distance. It all seemed so safe and tranquil.   8/10 play on ironman mode unless you're a massive faglord

Although I only played the original XCom: UFO Defense a little bit (didn't even beat the game), I was excited to hear about this game. I very much enjoyed turn-based squad combat games of the past and was excited to purchase this game. In most aspects this game met my expectations, although there are a few 'glitches' that can be frustrating.  The game has several frustrating bugs that can ruin your playing experience. I remember several times where I was attempting to move my units to a different level, only to have the camera spaz out and accidentally move my guys where I didn't want them to be. Also, sometimes you seemingly can't move to a valid location because the game will not register that you've moved up a level.   Not being able to direct your character's movements in a specific way really hurts this game. In the past XCom game, you could advance little-by-little instead of having to move in one big chunk. While I do agree that removing that from this game was the right decision, not being able to control how your guys get to their destination can prove deadly. Why would I want my guy to run blindly around cover or climb a building and then jump down again when he could have taken a much safe route to get to the same location? This has caused some frustrating deaths or inability to move my guys.  Also, the equipment management is not the easiest thing in the world to use. I've often found myself hunting down individual pieces of equipment from recovering soliders in order to outfit the squad I'm taking on my mission. It would be a lot easier if there was a global list of equipment we could assign rather than having to individually unequip items from soldiers not on the mission.  Although there are fan-made patches to solve some of these issues, the panic system is by far the most frustrating intended part of the game. I can recall several times where a squad member has, for some reason, paniced after someone took a grazing blow, shot his own squad member in the back of the head, which then proceeded to set off a chain reaction of panics and led to the entire squad suiciding after someone took a plasma blast to the arm. That's just frustrating game mechanics and doesn't really have a place here. I realize they were going for the squad panicing in a tough situation, and I know it's tied to will, but especially early on in the game, there's not a whole lot you can do about it. You certainly shouldn't have a good chance of your squad killing themselves at the slightest bit of panic. Hunkering down I can CERTAINLY understand, but all these random actions that they can perform is just ridiculous. It's a bad part of the old game and should have been done away with.  The overall graphical style of this game is excellent, the cut scenes are well played out, and I was actually surprised to note the impressive amount of depth they gave to uncovering what the aliens were actually doing on earth. As I played through it, I wanted to uncover more secrets to find out what exactly was happening with this invasion.  Recommended for anyone who like sci-fi, squad combat, turn-based, or casual gaming experiences.  Not recommended for those who like fast-paced games, don't like sci-fi, and are looking for detailed combat games.

But the climb, the work put into each facet of my facilities, and the well knit team I had crafted, all paid off. The tactics genre, the most frustrating of gameplay styles, does not overstay its welcome, instead it is well paced and fair in its gameplay. And even minor details are great. I cannot state it strongly enough - this game is absolutely amazing and if you are a fan of strategy games, you owe it to yourself to play it.   There are two modes to the game: Tactical turn based missions, and base planning in between missions.   The missions are fun and are an absolute blast. When you first start playing, you will probably die a lot, especially at one of the higher difficulty levels. You learn that you need to be careful, advance slowly (but not too slowly) and take chances that matter. Do you want to advance a little faster, maybe get a little bit better ground, knowing all too well that you might get ambushed and wiped out? Or do you want to advance at a snail's pace but then have all of your shots with low percentage hits because of the distance? One thing I will say - cover is your friend. And flanking attacks? Wonderful!  The base planning is a careful balancing act of where to spend money and what missions to take. You build your base, research tech, and decide which countries to save. You cannot save them all, and you will never have enough money, so you need to be very careful. Yeah, that new sniper rifle may be wonderful, but you could use those funds instead to build two new ships capable of intercepting UFO's. It is deep, and a very enjoyable aspect of the game. Personally, I like the base planning even more than the turn based combat, and that is saying A LOT.  After you beat the game, you get the option to turn on new features as well! Things like 'solider have random stats', or 'leveling up provides random bonuses', etc. Basically, you can add a lot more randomness to the game, which I think is a nice touch and gives it a lot of replayability. This is one of the very few games I have gone back to multiple times.  And finally - the expansion: Enemy Within. Holy heck... If you like the base game, you NEED the expansion. It makes the game so much better! They added more than enough features to justify the cost. You can make 'Mechs, you can genetically modify your troopers, they added more enemies with new surprises for you, and a completely additional mini-campaign with some new missions involved. I love the new mission types, especially the one you have to do as part of the regular campaign. I won't say more because I don't want to spoil it, but hands down, the expansion makes this amazing game even better.  I would rate it a 9/10 if you are a fan of turn based strategy and tough choices.  With the expansion, 10/10.

Everything about me wants to mark this as a 'YES'.  However, because of the problems with this game, I MUST give it a no. This game should be considered BETA at best. Unfortunately, most 'BETA' games on steam should be PRE-ALPHA so, my scale isn't quite the same as STEAM's.  Here's the major problems: - Game locks up into impossible situations - example: Character required to move, with no 'valid' locations to move. - Save system is WRETCHED!!! I can't under-emphasize this point, if the game did not have any lock-ups (which it does) you would want to plan for a gaming marathon, and never a short session, because the opportunities to save are few & far between. When you're at your base & hit [ESC] there's no menu to save, and when I've been on missions, there are two options 'Proceed, or Return' and 'return' does nothing. Why even make a button that does not work?  My personal grievance: So far there's one track to follow, and it is a buggy track. I got to a place that mandated 'Launching a missile' to continue, but there were no options to 'Launch a missile'. And since I could not save, I had to relaunch from a previous campeign, as there were no auto-saves either. I was completely stuck @ 'Launch missile to continue' and could not goto mission control, or the situation room, and those were two of the three buttons possible to push, the third was about events & that just told me nothing was upcoming. With nothing 'upcoming' and no way to leave a screen, because both buttons were broken, it became an eternity of hell, that I couldn't reload back to, as again, no save was available.  My personal praise: There are many redeeming aspects of this game. The concept is brilliant, and the action-sequences are amazing. I like the level of graphics, and a lot of work was done here. I'm looking forward to more from this developer & this makes me delighted at the prospect of multiplayer with this game-style.  Hopefully there will be an update that addresses these issues, until then, I need to keep my 'No' for recommendation.

Right off the bat, I have never played the original Xcom, and as such went into this game without preconceived notions. Overall, this is a good game with replayability value. Especially if you check out the long war mod.  What it doesn't do good, is the aiming system which partially relies on a, shall we say, way too random randomnumber generator. I've seen 1% hit and I've seen 100% miss, but most of the time if the aim is lower than 70%, you're more likely to miss than not. Sometimes it doesn't even help that you're standing adjacent to the enemy. Now this isn't awfully frequent, and certainly not frequent enough to ruin the game. But it is annoying when it does happen. And it doesn't really help that the enemy seemingly always have a bigger chance to hit than you. Furthermore, there are some problems with clipping and line of sight. There have been instances where you or the enemy is able to shoot through the wall. At other times, you feel like you ought to be able to see an enemy but cannot. Again, nothing frequent and nothing game breaking, just know that it can happen. The enemy also gets a free move action, when you discover them, which they'll use to run into cover if available, or sometimes even to flank you, giving them a big bonus to aim and critical damage chance.  The base game works really well even on lower end computers. I used to play it on a laptop with just one core. Now I say USED to, because once I upgraded to Xcom Enemy Within, the requirements changed to a minimum of two processor cores. Something I wasn't very happy about, especially since there was no warnings given. The DLCs available are overpriced and really should have been included with the basegame, it hardly offers naught. Yet the ability to change colors of uniforms and customize the soldiers costs extra. And yes, I do own all the DLCs, though I would strongly suggest getting them at a sale.  There could definately have been a few more maps, aliens and especially different types of missions. The missions consists of;  -Kill all enemies -Escort squishy and useless VIP -Disarm Bombs -Kill all enemies while rescuing idiotic civilians  And not much else, none of the DLCs or the Expansion offers much more variety either. But despite all the ways that the developers are cheap, greedy, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and the small ways in which the game is broken, it IS STILL FUN. No really, it is.

My definition of a strategy game isn't a turn-based game, but a real-time strategy like LOTR: Battle for Middle Earth or Command & Conquer. I have spent months of playing strategy games in my time, and I never did come to like Civilization or games like that.   XCOM: Enemy Unknown is an exception. The dynamics, the cinematics, everything about the game is great. The gameplay was very detailed and good for a turn-based strategy game. The story was okay, but what made it the most fun were the soldiers you commanded during the entire alien invasion. All the soldiers you receive are randomly generated, yes. But you can customize them to how you want, and I did just that. I didn't lose a single soldier the entire game, and I kind of bonded with 8 soldiers of mine that I would switch in and out depending on if any suffered injuries. Regardless, I ranked them up to the highest rank a soldier could receive and I really cared about their survival. Once you spend all that time ensuring they do the most amount of damage, surviving any damage, and tailoring them to how you want them to look, you bond with your soldiers.   I got this game when it was on sale and only because it was on sale. I really wish I looked into this game earlier. I recommend you get this game as soon as possible and have yourself a great experience. This game is well worth its fee.   The Bureau: XCOM Declassified on the other hand....well.....I got it for a dollar as part of a sale...don't buy that game.

Without a doubt, highly recommended. This game has very few shortfalls and was very entertaining - lots of replayability, though i would recommend buying its expansion pack at the same time; 'Enemy Within' as this allows far more customization of your individual soldiers as well as awards/medals and obviously, extra mission variation and content.  Pros: - well thought out and simple interface, everything has a purpose here and its explained well enough even for turn-base tactical rookies like myself, stats system is totally self explanitory. - looks good, weapons and explosions - buildings and destroyable cover. - engaging gameplay with a good prospect for replayability. - varied soldier types, nearly every perk is useful in some way and they can all support different playstyles, except snipers and squadsight ... that is the ONLY perk ive found you HAVE to pick. - every action has a consequence, you cant just bull rush the objective and not take casulties and casulties can cost you time or your best trained soldiers life, its also a game where you cannot save everyone - you must carefully manage how you respond to alien abductions and terror attacks to mimimize worldwide panic and keep x-com nations in the game. - encourages careful play with your assets, money, alloys, weapon parts and most importantly, troops - losing an experienced soldier can be disasterous, pro tip; always end your turn in cover! - like almost all turn based games, there is no limit on your turn - you can spend as long as you like considering your next move. - no autosave by default - its an option, but i believe the devs intended it to be a game that once youve made a choice its final but with the way gamers are these days, if there wasnt an autosave feature it would be considered herasy of the highest order. - soldiers behave like real troops under heavy pressure and may panic and make snap descisions.  Cons:  - Movement system is a little junky when working with altitudes, mech walkers jetboot module cannot see higher altitudes when there are movable tiles directly under them. - Grappling hooks on armor are buggy and may launch your troops across the map instead of say; climbing to the top of that building. - soldier voice packages are a little limited, even though Enemy Within added much more - many nationalities still lacked a flare in their speech and many languages were not included. - final boss fight easier than the battleship raid, infact, i believe the hardest mission i played was the one where you have to call down an airstrike and get out when youre surrounded by chrysalids. - too many troops, not enough bad guys!  All in all, if you like this genre of strategy game ... then this is definately a good game for you, if you can stand the sometimes infuraitaing RNG like missing on a 99% hit chance.

Fun, tactical, strategy squad/base building game where the fate of nations, indeed all of humanity, hangs in the balance with every mission choice. What it lacks in soldier customisation from the original UFO series, XCOM makes up for with beautiful graphics and fluid gameplay.   I have lost untold hours on this game, striving to keep my soldiers alive long enought to gain the skills they need to survive, and to research the technology required to combat the ever increasing intensity of the alien invasion.  I have cackled gleefully and mouthed 'Boom! Headshot!' as an elite sniper takes down an alien halfway across the map in glorious cinematic action. Gritted my teeth in exasperation and watched helplessly as nations critical to the funding of my XCOM forces were absorbed by the ever encroaching Alien forces. Cried out in dismay as veteran soldiers got cut down in battle and then desperately filled out my depleted forces with inexperienced rookies, praying they make it through the next mission.  This is a game that sucks hours out of your life until finally you either emerge bloody and victorious, or it crushes you in ignomious defeat. Overall game replayability is limited but there is some variation in the way you approach each mission tactically and the strategic campaign overall. Plus you can make big stompy cyborg troops and gentically enhanced super soldiers! This game is like a neverending supply of your favourite food of choice and you will find yourself gorging on it constantly, until you are sick of it, and take a long break from eating it again before returning to gorge on it once more. Or you won't.

I love this game.  In the single player campaign, you are the head of the world's secret military force designed to combat a major alien invasion force. The game is spent deligating research, construction, purchasing, and (to a much lesser degree) financial tasks. This is great fun as it adds a sort of overarching strategy to the game. However, the primary focus of the gameplay is on each individual mission. These playout as turn-based, squad-based, combat scenarios. They make for great fun. There are tactics such as flanking and cover bonuses. Shots are on a percentage chance to hit basis, which means you can sometimes have a glorious unlikely success, as well as a stunning unlikely defeat. While this adds a negative element of luck to a game of strategy, I feel the lack of certainty is realistic and adds a great element of intensity. You can customize and name your squad, which is great because, frankly, you grow attached to your soldiers. When one dies, they are gone for good, which helps add to the intensity mentioned above.  Pros: - Fun strategy and turn-based combat. Similar to a tabletop war game of some sort. - Single Player has an element of long-term strategy gaming which I enjoy. - You form surprising attachments to your squad members. - You will find yourself becomming emotionally involved. - The levels and events are mostly random - You often have to make hard decisions which can sometimes have very negative consequences. This isn't game ending.  Cons: - The game crashed on me twice.... That's really the only thing I can think of a the moment.  If you like turn-based combat, and/or tabletop war games, buy this game. If you hate turn-based combat, and/or tabletop war games, do NOT buy this game.

Everytime one of my units die, I find myself asking, 'Why XCOM, why do you do this to me?' and smiling at the same time. To sum this game up, it doesn't hand victory to you lightly, and it was designed as such. It is creative and has a lot to offer to the strategy genre of video games. In XCOM, you are the commander of an elite last defense called the XCOM project that is to be activated if/when aliens attack earth, and of course, aliens attack. You must fight back the alien threat with a squad of the finest soldiers from any and every country. The ultimate goal of the game is to defeat the alien threat and not get your funding pulled.  One of the things that makes the game so great is that it limits you to a certain extent. Certain classes can only weild certain weapons which are only good for certain things (I.E. A sniper will be horrible at point blank range with a sniper rifle). This helps make it so that a player doesn't become so overpowered that the game just isn't a challenge anymore.   Now, with any good game, there are some annoying cons. Sometimes, units can't see down ramps which makes it extremely hard to get rid of anything on said ramp and will likely kill your unit because of it. There are also some small visual bugs such as bullets coming out of a units side when he shoots at something, but it's more funny than annoying since it doesn't happen too often. Also, if you are to buy this game, you should note that it isn't very story driven.  For this game, I would not only recommend buying it but also the Enemy Within DLC which adds more missions, maps, and an entirely new enemy to the game (as if one wasn't enough).   So really, if you don't have this game already, you should get it. It has brought me lots of fun and well earned this review and it's way to the top of my favorites list.    (For those who hate reading things that long review)   Pros:     Good gameplay    Amazing DLC    Hard but fun at the same time    Creative   Cons     Small visual bugs    Line of sight bugs    No big storyline

I recall being distinctly unimpressed with this game upon first release. Yes, I was one of the throng who fondly remembered the original X-COM and believed that this game was a pale, dumbed-down remake for the console generation.  However, I recently dusted it off and gave it another try. I've been pleasantly surprised.   I'm not going to sit here and say it's a great game, because the strategic part still feels to me like it's on rails and is way more restricting than I'd like. I also won't go in to the myriad reasons why the strategic element is a let down, because three years after release you can bet everyone else has already covered all my possible gripes.  What I will say is that the tactical element has a lot more depth than I first gave it credit for. I don't particularly care for the way the aliens are 'activated', but that aside the battlefield abilities of the various classes and the mechanics of cover and elevation make for a rewarding - sometimes even nail-biting - experience.  If you were sorely disappointed that this wasn't a direct X-COM remake when if fitst hit the shelves, maybe it's time you gave it another chance. If you can overlook the controversially 'streamlined' elements of the strategic side you just might find an enjoyable squad-level tactical simulation underneath.  Recommended, but not without reservations: 6.5-7/10

Great Game. 9.5/10  There is some real polish to this game, the graphics, animations and sound are solid, as are the unit and camera controls.  Xcom lets you customize your soldiers, upgrade them and reward them accordly. This forms a kind of bond and makes you really feel the impact of permanent death and adds real consequences to your choices.  The difficulty of the game seems to plateau at about 1/3 of the way thru. Early on soldiers will die if an alien lands any kind of a hit on them, this makes the first handful of missions very challenging and critical. If you fail an early mission you are out men, money and your terror level will increase, which can easly snowball into losing Xcom councel members and funding. Once you get past this stage in the game, you should have things on lock to the point where losing men and being short on funds will not directly lose you the game. The difficulty does rachet up later as new aliens, weapons and ablitlies are introduced however never to the point of the early game.  The ending of the game seems a little abrupt, thankfully Xcom is more about the journey than the destination. I do wish there was a dooms day clock or some mechanic that forces the player to move quicker and make harder choices near the end. As it stands, at the end game you can sit on your hands finish off your research, engineer anything you want and level up soldiers until you have the perfect squad to send out.  The AI is just smart enough to catch and kill you if you're not paying attention. However after a while you can easily predict how it will react to a situation and use that to your advantage.  I appreciate the 'Ant Farm' base building, dispite it being fairly simple. I really wish the base assault mission used your base's layout, (Old School Xcom) instead of just a generic base map. Being able to zoom in and look around is a nice touch.  The technology tree is alittle weak and pretty linear, it does and has just enough to get by. You will find some items you can skip completely, while others are forced on you to progress the story. That's not really a problem, it is what it is.  Multiplayer is flat and boring. There is a point system you use to select troops and a handful of map to play on. I really wish there was a CoOp option.  The DLC adds some nice additions to the game, more maps, couple missions, Mech and Cyber Soldiers and more customization.  Solid replayablity, some combat maps can become repedative; achievements, DLC, difficulty settings, and a little combat RNG helps.  Xcom is what I expect out of my turn based strategy games, it sets the bar.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a brilliant strategy game that hits all the right notes for its genre.   Pros: 'Ant farm' mode is surprisingly absorbing, rather than feeling like the downtime between missions. Managing the base adds to the sensation of being a military commander. You get to decide the direction XCOM will go in and make decisions to adjust your combat style past just moving your soldiers from tile to tile. Speaking of combat, I'm a big fan of the percentage chance for hitting/missing shots. Rather than weapons dealing less damage in improper conditions or only working in a certain range, you have the chance to miss entirely. This encourages strategic play (i.e. moving your assault with a shotgun into a flanking postion rather than trying to snipe from the minimum distance). Moreover, it adds to the sensation of real combat; despite all your planning, things can and will go wrong. Difficulty is high enough so that you have to at least be trying and have some idea of what you're doing but not to the point where it's frustrating to progress. Finally, despite the non-procedurally generated maps and exact same story every playthrough, the randomness of UFO encounters and diversity of combat options adds a lot of replay value. That, and the Long War mod (but that's a whole seperate beast).   Cons: Despite what you'd expect, the game gets progressively easier as time goes on. Once you get the hang of combat and stop doing stupid stuff like ignoring council missions (give me a break, it was my first playthrough) it's just a matter of when the technology comes along and your soldiers level. Challenge is lost when your squad consists of six colonels with plasma weapons. The only thing that can really make the game suddenly harder is losing part of your team. Which is another problem; it is exceptionally easy to screw up your game. One mistake in combat can cost you all your soldiers and council nations without much you can do to fix it. I love a challenge, but save scumming often seems unavoidable with XCOM.   Overall, I'd still suggest XCOM: Enemy Unknown to almost all gamers. It's fun, addictive, immersive, and provides some of the best victories to be had in gaming. Ayylmao/10.

I recommend this game but be warned: it has bugs and glitches.  Pros:  +Its fun and addicting, turn based, tactical, strategy game. +There's a lot of game (good value), that will keep you wondering what happens on the next turn. (I've come to expect this from Firaxis.) +Critical thinking and management game -- you manage your XCOM base, and depending on your performance, you either keep or lose nation (members) for your XCOM project. +Interesting plot, and CGI/voice acting isn't too bad. +It's really cool when you're tasked to capture an alien. You have to critically think of strategies to keep your troops alive and not get hurt while they attempt to do this. +The best strategy is, if you can employ it, rather than letting your troops take damage, which requires them time to heal, try to find a way to never let them get hurt in the first place. I found by playing with this as my priority, it seriously has helped my overall strategizing. Sometimes you can't help it. +It's a lot of fun just blowing the hell up out of some important building, and getting paid for it because aliens are present. Having to use rockets on a particular office building, or having to use grenades next to vehicles can make some spectacular explosive displays.  Cons: -Though I have never seen it crash to desktop, it has completely froze on me, usually right at the start of the AI's turn. I can move the mouse but the UI doesn't come back.  -I don't know what it is about the Berserker Muton but whenever this particular unit has a move, the game gets severely choppy; I guess it's because the camera anchors to this unit and it causes slow down/staggering. -I have lost a troop due to it getting it's foot stuck in the floor. I literally have had to fight an entire mission down a man, not because he was dead, but because I couldn't move him because he was glitched for some reason. -I have had to reload missions simply due to mis-clicking on a tile for a troop to move to, and have him going to some other tile. Sometimes, the isometric perspective doesn't work best, especially when you're going through an alien base or a large alien ship (like a supply ship), and you have multiple levels to deal with. This creates havoc for the already problematic unit placing tool. -Other note on the unit placing tool: it's glitchy. Attempting to move a unit to a particular location on a floor could have the floor or roof intervening on your placement, right at the time you're about to click, thus placing the unit in a bad position. It just seems to cause the floor or roof to disappear by 'flickering' on and off and is extremely annoying. I've had to reload games due to this. -Probability chance of getting a hit or being hit seems to be off by a mile at times. I don't know what it is, there's just something wrong when you go to take a shot, like say, a Sniper with a 98% chance to hit a target and he misses. Crap like that has me uttering bad words... Sometimes I wonder if the % chance to hit even makes sense in this game because I really don't think it does. I have missed enemy combatants with 85-98% chance to hit and it blows me away that when they make the same moves, they never miss. You'd think that a troop that is aiming at an enemy combatant would have the same chances as the enemy combatant in terms of hitting. Sometimes, it feels like 50/50, regardless what the aiming tooltip has to say. -Some annoyances in regards to the back and forth motion of the camera; as it zooms to whichever unit's turn it is, so you can better plan your move. Personally, I don't care about the presentation so much, especially after I'm hooked after 15 hours of gameplay; at this point, all I want to do is just play. But it's so annoying when you want to take your move and the screen is bouncing around from enemy to friendly because it has to do it's little 'focus' effect, where it centers the camera right on top of the unit whose turn it is to move. Very annoying, especially when you already know where you want to throw the grenade/launch a rocket, then you click the button on the unit for it, and it goes back to focusing/centering on the unit again, so you have to find again, the spot for launching said rocket/grenade to. And then misclicking at this time can have terrible consequences -- especially if you're not intending it, you'll have to reload your game. -I found the mini cinematics, such as watching your troop fire/throw a grenade/run to a certain location to be pointless. Deactivating them doesn't seem to speed up the game, now you just wait the 3-4 seconds instead of seeing a little cinematic, in place of watching the cinematic, as if the cinematic is playing in the background. -Would be nice if it let you customize the individual settings for like say, map scroll speed, if whether or not it will focus/center the mouse on every action for every troop (actions being grenade toss, rocket launch), the area of map scrolling (how close the mouse has to be to the edge for the map to move left or right, up or down). If whether or not you can go with a more basic tile selecting tool because the one in the game, as it is now, is very glitch and feels resource demanding (is slow in later levels, when there's a lot going on). -There have been times when I lost units that have been standing next to a vehicle, that doesn't appear to be on fire, but is actually on fire. But I wouldn't know it until after it explodes. Very annoying to discover this. I have determined that the tiny little fire on the inside of the car window, that is visible at any angle, indicates the vehicle is on fire.  -The difficulty of the game ramps up incredibly, especially after you're able shoot down a UFO that is known for taking out satellites. It becomes incredibly important to capture any alien you come across, and sometimes, they're incredibly strong. It only makes you wonder how can you possibly budget to have the best gear for your men and at the same time, have enough funding to launch all the satellites you need for all the members of your XCOM project? For instance: going against the Red Mutons that have plasma laser guns is an extremely bad idea, if all you have is carapace armor and less than plasma sniper rifles, since these guys can hit you at an incredibly long range, for a lot of health damage, and don't take much damage themselves.  -Snipers seem to be so important after just a little while. They have incredibly useful talents, such as being able to target foes that are visible by other troops. I find bringing at least two to every mission to be detrimental, while Support is okay, as long as you don't use any variation of the shotgun, and run&gun ability is totally stupid, except in situations where it means you have completed a mission or saved a fellow troop -- otherwise, it's just an excellent way to lose a troop; and Heavy is terrible at long range, and will miss just about every time, but is awesome for the rockets it can launch, as well as the suppression ability -- detrimental for catching aliens. So, I think there's some balancing issues with the classes and how they come together.  -Some abilities can't be lived without and some are totally pointless.  I know, I bellyached quite a bit but it's the little things that kill in a game like this. Honestly, the game is quite fun and playable, as long as you can put up with all of it's frequently occuring glitches.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a Turn-based, tatical, Sci-fi stratgey game that I was sceptical about going into to, seeing as console ruined my first impressions of this game. When I got into PC, however, I was amazed at how good the game actually was.  In XCOM, you are the commander of a strike team, under the project XCOM opperation, to liberate all the aliens on Earth, and save the planet. It is VERY turned based, and forces you to think on the spot, most of the time, when you are pinned to walls against hostile ailens. The game is also very difficult. Even on normal mode, the game is tough. There will be times when you are yelling at your computer screens to try and tell your team to 'learn to aim', and other times, you will hoping that they recieve promotions and don't die.  There are some more aspects of the game, however. You need to manage the research department, to make sure the stuff that you salvage off of the remains of aliens can be studied and more thoroughly understood. There is also the workshop, wheer you can craft items to help your strike team in battle, to help other nations, and to help to fight against UFO's. You also need to manage your crew, make sure they have the best stuff they can, and make they get their promotions.  Overall, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is an amazing game, that I will definitly play more of. This is a game that I HIGHLY recommend to all players out there who REALLy like to think and analize things in games, but also, have a great time and feel satisfied after each victory.

Ok, strap in boys and girls 'cause this is gonna be a fairly long one(I think).  The game is about a secret task force, the titular XCOM, that has to defend Earth against an invading alien force with unclear motives. You need to help various countries that are invested in the XCOM project, as your lose condition is losing too many countries to the alien threat.  Let's get the main flaws out of the way first. The game doesn't exactly feel entirely complete without the Enemy Within expansion which along with the base game makes the price a bit high at first glance for a 3-4 year old game. However, it could be that the expansion adds so much that it's hard to think of the game without it.  Also, the Normal difficulty feels much too easy after a certain point in the game, to the degree where I could aggro 3 enemy squads/pods(something which is very stupid, you should only aggro 1) and take them out easily. To get a better experience of the game, to really immerse yourself in the atmosphere of the game which asks you to take on an unknown enemy, you have to play on the harder difficulties.  Another complaint, albeit a somewhat subjective one, is that weapons don't really have the variety that is present with the different types of armor. There is an armor type that grants extra HP, another 2 that amplify your soldiers mobility, one that grants the ability to turn invisible, so on and so forth. With weapons however, all classes are limited to having one type of weapon(with the exception of Assault). All new weapons that you develop are incremental improvements over their previous iterations. Perhaps it would've been nice to add some abilities depending on the weapon itself in order to make them more varied.  Another thing is that the soldier customization is disappointingly bare-bones, it's hard to make soldiers distinguishable from one another without giving them something ridiculous(my favourite soldier was Guile Theme, named so due to his fabulously ridiculous blonde hair). This is probably fixable with some mods though.  Lastly, the game is fairly buggy. Crashes are pretty infrequent, but I've had more than too many situations where the game would get stuck in one animation and I would have to restart it in order to continue or when the movement UI wouldn't work properly and I would accidentally expose a soldier.  Enough with the downers, now with the positives.  The gameplay is INSANELY fun. XCOM: Enemy Unknown is turn/squad based and you have to use cover smartly in order for your soldiers to survive and you have to think of ways of defeating enemies that are (most of the time) in solid cover themselves. It is amazing trying to outflank or flushing them out of cover with explosives, not to mention a large variety in enemies and tactics to handle each. The basic formula is extremely simple, yet it proves addictively fun.  The variety in soldier classes is also a strong pro. There are 4 basic classes with 2 others discoverable later in game(provided you have Enemy Within installed). That might not sound like a lot, but there are numerous combinations of classes that you can try in a squad. What's more, each class has various abilities that have a mutually exclusive alternative and those make the soldier play differently from one of the same class, but with a different selection of abilities.  Lastly, the game has plenty of time/money value, warranting multiple playthroughs on different difficulties, with Second Wave settings that also change the game and after that you can also try the Long War mod which is supposed to overhaul the game entirely, though I cannot say more on this since I did not try it. However, just one playthrough of the campaign took me more than 30 hours with a lot more to try left.  Some mediocre aspects of the game now.  Story. It's mysterious at first, becomes increasingly meh in the mid to late game and becomes interesting again at the end. Basebuilding outside missions. Crucial to your performance, but dull. Slingshot DLC is meh.  That's about it, overall a definite recommendation for any strategy game fan and a good way to get non-fans started on the genre.

Does lots of things really well. In particular the character animations and body language, the voice casting/acting and referential sci fi aesthetics are all superb and possibly revolutionary. The music evokes Morricone's theme for Carpenter's 'The Thing' - a big plus for me.  Crits are mighty satisfying too.  The camera is bloody awful. It continuously removes you, the player, from the equation. I'll explain; You make the last move of your turn. Perhaps you uncover some more aliens during that move on top of the ones you're already engaging. Perhaps you immediately realise that the move was an error and would simply like to load your last save. Tough luck. Now you sit there locked out of both the menu and the camera while it flits from alien move to alien move (much more snappily than if you had control of it I might add) - this could be 10+ aliens. After it's shown you all those alien moves it'll then move through any other incidents, like maybe some of your squad panicked or were poisoned or some npc dialogue in one of the (ugh) extraction missions. If any vehicles were on fire and due to explode it will move through these too. Then, after all this, you can take your thumb out of your behind and access the menu or move the camera again. The camera is also buggy and will frequently fly off on it's own into the fog of war and expect you to fetch it back ... when it's not falling through the environment.  Free aim is also a joke, clearly not optimised for anything other than controller input. Certain reproducable conditions will freeze/crash the game - known bugs that were never fixed. Line of sight is ropey. Sometimes aliens just appear out of nowhere in a room you're in (this is rare though). The so called 'rng' is also very strange. Of a particularly dubious nature is the chance for your Heavy's rocket to fire off target. Lord only knows what this chance is based on.  Thing is, all these things can be brushed off for the first few play-throughs or on difficultys up to and including classic iron man, 'cos it's a cool sci fi game, but once you're into impossible difficulty territory then they really start to get on your nerves.  Also, if you're into achievements, then you better buy Enemy Within, otherwise you'll be stuck at just above half completion since EU achievements are not separated. Reasonable proof that EW content should have been part of EU in the first place and was taken out to be sold to you for another £20 later on.  In the end though, I grudgingly recommend it.

XCOM is the best kind of strategy game. It's the kind of game that makes you second-guess nearly every choice you make. Throughout the entire early-to-mid game, you have way more options available than you have resources with which to invest in those options. Do you research plasma weapons or hover armor? Or, if you've researched both already, do you BUILD plasma weapons or hover armor? That's just when you're at base; when you're on the battlefield, you have an entirely different set of options to constantly second-guess. You WILL, at some point, spot a group of aliens during your last action of the turn, and they WILL get first dibs on retaliating. Sometimes they'll rock your world, sometimes they won't, but the mere threat of them rocking your world is enough to make you load your last save.  Fortunately, on the default difficulty setting, the game is quite forgiving of mistakes, because the AI is intentionally dumbed down, sometimes to the point that enemies do literally nothing on their turn. You can still complete the game even if you make several 'wrong' choices. Especially because, as implied in the last paragraph, save scumming is an integral part of keeping the game going. Save early and often. (It baffles me than Ironman mode even exists...and further baffles me that people have completed it.)

An easy recommendation for people who like turn based tactics games.  Be aware though: Enemy Unknown relies heavily on percentages to hit. You can mitigate that to a pretty decent extent, but just remember that a 99% chance to hit can still fail. Plan ahead.  The game consists of 2 layers. The first one is the meta game, building your base, conducting research, hiring and training new soldiers, etc. The second one is the actual combat, of which there is a lot. The 2 layers work hand in hand. You need a strong base and a good economy to actually have enough well trained soldiers to stand a chance in the battles themselves. These battles are turn based. You control up to 6 soldiers, all with potentially unique skills and gear. You are forced to make use of cover, otherwise your soldiers will drop like flies. Cover reduces the chance to be hit...but not the actual damage received. Same goes for the aliens of course. Flanking is a thing and is required in order to be effective. Same goes for height advantage. It's really quite an intricate system. Flanking an opponent often guarantees you a 100 chance to hit. Every hit can also be a crit if you have the right modifiers on your guys.  Missions vary from rescuing civilians to securing objects or killing all aliens. Actually there's not that much variation, but there are a lot of different maps and setups that still make it interesting. I strongly advise you to disable the action cam pretty soon. It gets lame and annoying quickly. Enemies can be captured, killed or 'obliterated' (with explosives). Capturing enables you to interrogate them (once per species) and to grab their weapons intact. Killed enemies leave weapon fragments behind, which are necessary for upgrades. Explosives are strong, but if an enemy is killed by them, all equipment is lost.  The later stages of the game introduce a LOT of different options and concepts, especially with the Enemy Within expansion, which adds a new resource type to genetically enhance your soldiers (higher jumping, immune to mind control, better perception, etc.) and turn them into cybernetic supersoldiers (MECs), which are the ultimate warrior, but require a lot of resources and research. Seriously though, the game has so many different resource types and things to do, it's hard to get it all done. On my easy playthrough I had 2 MEC soldiers and only a few genetic upgrades, because everything costs everything kinda. Would you rather invest in genetically enhanced soldiers, MECs, items, or maybe fighter jets and improvements for them? On easy, this is not so much a problem, but on the harder difficulties you will feel every death of a really good soldier, you will have to decide which countries you want to save, which research you want to pursue and which battles you can win. Play on Iron Man and every decision is final. No going back to another save file.  And trust me, the game can be brutal. You can dominate your enemies, but all it takes is one mistake or a little bit of bad luck for one or two of your soldiers getting insta killed. And here lies my one big gripe with the game: Enemy movement. Whenever you move across the map (from cover to cover) you can trigger enemy movement, i.e. you can encounter a pack of enemies, which then get a free move (at least they can't attack you yet). There is no real way to surprise enemies. Maybe with enough heigth advantage or the 'cloaking armor'. When fighting these enemies and maneuvering around you may just trigger another group...and so on. Things can quickly escalate, especially in the later stages of the game, which fields much stronger enemies as your soldiers get stronger as well.  Enemy Within also introduces another enemy: The Exalt...human traitors. They are the single most boring thing in the expansion. Their missions are interesting exactly once. After that you have to SUFFER through the same cutscenes over and over and over again, since they are not skippable. Yes, I know I have to hack the radio towers...good god. The missions aren't even particularly fun...and you will be doing a lot of them until you find their base of operations, which is an anticlimactic fight. So disappointed with these. They're also pretty weak. Your specialists will melt them.  Apart from that it's a really fun game. Go get it!

Every layer of this game is satisfying, from the individual movement of units to designing your home base. The added randomization from the 'Enemy Within' expansion makes individual soldiers more interesting and the timed objectives keep you from slogging slowly through each level. Buy both and play them for 100 hours.

Cons:   'Multiplayer' (separate from Campaign mode, and you can ignore multiplayer completely if you like) apparently = strictly 1-on-1 PVP, no co-op, which I'd have preferred.  I lost my second favorite soldier to the 'Wounded bug' I've since found mentioned by other players. That's where after being wounded in battle a soldier rarely may sit at the bottom of the roster Wounded, unusable, with no timeclock, forever. Characters stuck this way (and undeletable, too) apparently can never be recovered unless you have a save to restore to in which they're not bugged, which I no longer did by the time I understood what had happened.  Sometimes the RNG just seems to be out for some nice, yummy player blood.   Pros:  It arrived, I installed it, I sat down to play it, I looked up and holy crap the sun was rising... And I wanted to keep playing.  I got hit by the accursed Wounded bug, and I still wanted to keep playing.  I got crushed in a campaign battle in which several of my soldiers had an 80+% chance to hit, they missed every shot, and the aliens proceeded to hog all the good dicerolls for themselves and plasma-BBQ my team in two rounds. I still wanted to keep playing.  My friend and much more experienced XCOM player repeatedly kicked my butt into a new postal code in PVP mode... while I flew the clueless newbie flag high and goofed up in every imaginable way and a few ways I wouldn't have imagined... and I still want to keep playing and to someday, if not win, then at least fail less hard in a rematch.  I could say stuff about the playstyle, the battle system, the graphics and the sound, and some of it would be flattering and some of it wouldn't.   But every negative I've encountered is vastly outweighed by 'I want to keep playing'.

If you  haven’t  heard or played the original XCOM before, that’s alright; because unless you're new to turn-based genre, you’ve certainly played games that have been deeply influenced by the genre that XCOM wrought in its wake. There had been other titles that relied heavily on turn-based combat mechanics of course, but XCOM was among the first to successfully put forth a real-time management simulation. It isn’t just about shooting aliens dead, you also have to manage a base of operations that includes research queues (that relies on your procurement prowess on the battlefield), manufacturing, recruitment, and armory. The management isn't very deep though nor does it have to be- but it does give you that sense of semi-foreboding in that recent decisions might come back to bite you withinin a few days of in-game time. Especially in  Ironman Impossible , the game's premiere unforgiving difficulty level.   Though the game offers plenty of action, it’s more about thinking things through, rather than operating on run-and-gun adrenaline that rewards you down the line.   Le Gud
